name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 31 January 2019.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: This afternoon we named the European Parliament radio studio in Strasbourg after Antonio Megalizzi and Bartosz Piotr Orent-Niedzielski, the two young journalists... (Applause) ... They lost their lives in the attack in Strasbourg on 11 December. I greet on behalf of all of you their families who are with us today.  (Applause) Sixty days have passed since that cowardly attack on our values and our way of life. Today's ceremony is a strong signal that we do not want to forget the victims of terrorism and that we always defend the right of journalists throughout the world to be able to tell what is happening and to discover the truth.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask the following question in Italian in order to avoid any misunderstanding. What he said now is fine with me: the hatred that was there is no longer there. That is why it is important to say the right words. Saying Italian Istria, Italian Dalmatia, can also have other meanings. I would ask you to clarify this, because your statement has not been taken well. It could be dangerous. I give you the opportunity, Mr President, and I would ask you to clarify these statements, because it is very important for the people who live in Istria today, for the exiles. I did bilingual school in Istria with my friends and I want to live in peace. Help us, thank you.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Honour president, I thank you for clarifying yesterday's statement, because what was understood yesterday in slovenia and Croatia, as my colleague Jakovčič said, was completely different.  And the term Italian Istria, Italian Dalmatia inadvertently returned us not only to the times after The Second World War and to events that slovenians, Croats, Italians all regret, but also to the times after The First World War, when Italian fascism caused great threedism to this part of Slovenia, Croatia, Europe. I would like to thank you once again for this clarification, and I would like us to conclude this subject in this spirit, because otherwise the matter goes into very wrong waters and is not in the spirit of the 21st century, and I know that you are not seeking hatred, but for friendship. I would therefore like to thank you once again for your apology and ask you for a clear explanation to the people along the border who expect this.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I think I have always demonstrated this by going, even during my term of office, to the border between Italy and Slovenia, so going from one side to the other, and there were also Members of the European Parliament with me. I just wanted to remember the victims of a violence that was the result of the hatred of that time, that no longer exists. I pointed out, also in an article that I wrote in an important Italian newspaper, that the peoples today live in peace with each other. I have been to Croatia several times, I have been several times to Slovenia, as I have been to Montenegro and Serbia. For my part there is absolutely no revanchist intention, there was only the feeling of remembering someone who had lost his life in those horrible years.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I think you should fence more because the whole of Croatia, the whole of Slovenia is buzzing about it. You know very well that Dalmatia and Istria are Croatian regions, namely those that suffered badly under Italian occupation and felt all the horrors of the fascist conquering regime. Without any intention of diminishing the importance of remembering the victims of communist crimes because my family also suffered under the communist boot, I find it shameful that the Speaker of Parliament represents imperialist aspirations and openly claims other people's territory. Your speech in Trieste, at least as interpreted through the media, Mr. President, among the Croats of Istria and Dalmatia has awakened exuberance memories of fascism, occupation, persecution, murder, abuse and systematic imposition of italian language and culture on the Croatian people. Please really clarify because, as I said, the whole of Croatia is buzzing about it.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I never wanted to impose the use of the Italian language on anyone. All I said was that there were Italians who died, and there are still many Italians who are exiles from those lands. However, there was no territorial claim, and I was referring to a specific case, which was that of the foibe, not to what had happened in the past. It seems to me that my position is very clear, so much so that I denounced in my speech the horrors of both materialisms, of both dictatorships of the past century.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, a delegation from this Parliament visited Nicaragua a fortnight ago. We visited prisons where political prisoners are suffering horrific abuse. There is a horrible bankruptcy of democratic freedoms in that country. And while President Ortega promised the European Parliament delegation that he would do something to smooth out the situation of the bankruptcy of democracy and human rights in that country, nothing is happening. On the contrary, everything is going to get worse. Mr President, I am going to address to you, on behalf of the delegation of the European Parliament that visited Nicaragua, a letter for you to address the President of that country to demand respect for freedoms and respect for human dignity in prisons.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Así lo haré.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, I didn’t want to get involved in the previous debate. You have always been a strong defender of the right of journalists to be protected, as you’ve shown in debates on the attacks on journalists in Turkey and also in Venezuela. You’ve also defended the human rights of those demonstrating for freedom in their countries. Can we therefore have your assurance that this House will seek to have a debate and a motion about the 12 weeks of attacks by Mr Macron on people, including journalists, in France, and in particular Paris, who are seeking to exercise their demonstrating rights, and about the numbers of journalists who have suffered personal injury and damage as a result of attacks by the stormtroopers set on them by Mr Macron’s police?

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, I had asked for the floor, although my colleague Jáuregui has already said so.  A fortnight ago we were in Nicaragua and at that time we visited a prison. We visited "La Esperanza", a prison of political prisoners who spoke to us and told us about the injustice of their cause and the physical and moral abuse they were receiving.  We demand that there be no retaliation against these dams who had dared to denounce what was happening. We ask the prison authorities, the Deputy Minister and President Ortega himself. He guaranteed us there would be no retaliation. Last Friday, we were confirmed that ten prey from one of the cells we were in had been mistreated, terribly beaten and also prevented from being visited by their relatives. I believe that the European Union cannot look the other way, neither Parliament, which does not, nor the Vice-President he sees. And we have to act immediately. In Nicaragua, I am convinced that terror reigns, there is no freedom for journalists, it beats prey, it kills students. I don't think we can look the other way.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I am pleased that you share Mr Jáuregui's position, which I believe is the position of the whole Parliament. That's why I'm sending the letter to the president of Nicaragua.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: Mr President, just a point of precision. Since it is journalism, it is as precise, accurate and in line with reality: it was not the police who attacked the journalists, ladies and gentlemen, it was protesters, whose side they came from elsewhere, or violent peripheral elements, with the demonstrators, who attacked journalists. And I thank you, when you speak on these subjects, for reading the press well, which is quite precise.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, it has now been a fortnight since Mrs Asia Bibi was finally acquitted in Pakistan of an accusation brought against her for blasphemy. Pakistan's supreme court has finally acquitted her after nine years of death. The problem now is that it is totally unknown where she is. Mrs Bibi and her family would like to leave Pakistan, but her lawyer is no longer in contact with her either. And I know that you have occasional good contacts with the Pakistani government. So my request to you is, Mr President – you have also spoken to the lawyer and Mr Weber did so just before the turn of the year – you would urge the Pakistani Government that Mrs Asia Bibi should now be released and be allowed to go to the country she wants to go to. Thank you.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr van Dalen, I have spoken to the Prime Minister of Pakistan about this matter, and I have had assurances the day after the Court's decision. If you think it appropriate, I can call him back and ask for news of Asia Bibi and his family. It seems to me, however, that the intention is to protect her and to get her out of the country with every guarantee of security for her safety, which is in the interests of this Parliament.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I bring to this House the anger, despair and tragedy of an entire people, that of the shepherds of Sardinia, who are currently pouring all their product, all their milk, into the streets. They throw it on the street, a white river that is spilled onto the street. Rather than being hungry they prefer to make the choice to throw away their product. It is a concept of dignity, strength and pride of an entire people, the Sardinian people, serious, straight, which cannot be treated in this way. Mr President, I believe that the industrialists and multinationals of large-scale distribution cannot, either in Sardinia or in all regions of Europe, fulfill the condition of imposing their diktats in order to starve an entire producing people. So we need immediate action, and above all this intervention must also look at product certification, combined certainly with another great aspect, that of fair competition. We cannot transfer products that come from outside to give it a different brand and origin. So I'm with the Sardinian shepherds. Of course I know that there must be mediation, mediation which means bargaining between supply and demand, and so I ask you, Mr President, to be able to meet a delegation of the same pastors in these days.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 7 February 2019. The following amendments have been tabled: On Monday, the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) called for the oral question on 'Large Predators' to become a Statement by the Commission. The debate should end with a resolution to be voted on in March I. Mr Noichl to make his group's request.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much for the floor. You have just rightly mentioned it: it is a question of a question on the subject of 'big predators' on the one hand, a question for oral answers and, on the other hand, a resolution to be adopted. I would like to stress once again that this issue has not been discussed before in the Committee on Agriculture. It is not a normal procedure. I have to be very clear. that the members of the Committee on Agriculture and Development did not have the opportunity to study and vote on the text. At the moment it has been proposed that the oral question should be put on the table this evening and that the resolution should be adopted on Thursday.  I hereby request that the oral question be replaced by an opinion from the Commission and that the resolution be postponed until March. I think we have enough time to proceed in the right way here with a proper, proper procedure. We should not refer to a speeding procedure which does not give any justification at all.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to the requests for Tuesday. On Tuesday, the S&D and Verts/ALE Groups requested that an oral question to the Commission on the future of the list of LGBTI actions be added to the agenda and be discussed in conjunction with the oral question on the rights of persons involved. The debate on the new oral question should end with a resolution. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Mr Keller to make the request.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we would like to ask that the oral question on the future of the LGBTI list of actions be added to the already existing debate on the oral question on the rights of intersex people and we would like to conclude that debate with a resolution. We would like to also ask for a roll-call vote right now. The reason we are asking for that debate and the resolution is because we see how attacks on LGBTI people are increasing all over Europe. We see a real setback and a backlash here, and the Commission needs to stand firmly on that matter. However, the list of actions on LGBTI rights by the Commission is actually running out. It expires this year and the Commission is actually reluctant to continue having a list of actions. This is our last chance as Parliament to push the Commission to act and to do something, because LGBTI rights are human rights and that’s why we should have a debate with resolution.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to the requests for Wednesday. On Wednesday, The S&D Group requested that a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union on the "Future of the INF Treaty and its impact on the EU" be added as the first item in the time slot 18.00-24.00. The debate should end with a resolution. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Moody to submit his group's request.

name: Clare MOODY
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this Parliament needs to take a clear position on the future of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty. Therefore, we need a debate with resolution on this matter this week. The NATO foreign ministers in the Munich Security Conference will be discussing it this week and this Parliament should have a position before they meet given its direct and major impact on the citizens that we are all here to represent. The INF Treaty has ensured the reduction of thousands of weapons covered by the Treaty and it has increased all of our safety. On that basis, we need to support the rules-based order and nowhere is that more important than in arms control. This Parliament needs to make its position clear this week and I therefore hope colleagues will support this addition to the agenda.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) has requested that the debate on Mr Zīle's report on 'Common rules for access to the international market for bus and coach services' be postponed to a later stage. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Mr Van Brempt to make the request.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group I would like to ask for the postponement of the Zīle report. This is not only a controversial report where groups need some extra time to prepare themselves, but more fundamentally this report is very much connected to a very highly controversial and difficult mobility package that also has been postponed. In order to organise the access of buses and coaches it is extremely important that we make sure that the working conditions of the people working for the buses and coaches, and the truck drivers, are assured and furthermore strengthened in the future. So that’s why we ask for a postponement to a later stage.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, Mr Zīle has asked me to make a few comments on this. Firstly, this report was simply discussed in the Transport Committee. There was broad support, including from part of the Socialist group. Moreover, if you simply read what is in the report, it is clearly stated that this is not about a total liberalisation of the bus transport market or about the subverting of the rights of people working in bus transport companies. On the contrary, there are all sorts of safeguards built into the report to ensure that existing good systems in bus transport are maintained and that new bus transport systems have a proper check on what effect this has on workers, what effect it has on the region, on the quality of transport. In short, there is a whole set of measures in that report laid down and worked out in the Transport Committee. I would therefore like to see this report on the agenda on behalf of Mr Zīle.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, in the light of that vote, this report was put on the agenda at a very late stage. Under Rule 169, Members reaching the lower threshold should be allowed to consider their position. They weren’t given sufficient time to consider their position. The deadline for amendments is currently 7 o’clock tonight. I would ask you, in the light of this rather controversial report, if you could extend it by 24 hours at least.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The terms were decided by the Conference of Presidents, so I do not think we can change any more, it is not the President's choice. If the groups agree, we can go to the maximum at 1.00 p.m. tomorrow, but we cannot go any further.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Mr President, if the Conference of Presidents decides to put a controversial file at such a late stage to plenary, I think it’s no more than fair for Members to be able to organise themselves. So let’s take a vote to postpone the deadline for 24 hours please.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: For services, the deadline is 1.00 p.m. tomorrow, if not, I cannot even make the proposal. Do we agree without a vote? I think we are in agreement, so let us postpone the deadline until 1.00 p.m. tomorrow. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has requested that the Council and Commission statements on 'Security threats related to the increased Chinese technological presence in the EU and possible action at EU level to reduce these threats' be added in the afternoon or evening. The debate should end with a resolution to be voted on in March. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Niedermayer to make the request.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Czech authorities are not the only ones who issued security warnings concerning certain technologies, especially in the area of data mobile telephonics. I guess there are more such European governments and it is a good time to discuss whether there shouldn’t be some kind of concentrated European action on how to ensure the security of our key infrastructure. At the same time, we should take a closer look at the development of the market, the high penetration of some firms and possible implications for the future of European markets.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, the reason I am speaking out against this proposal is not so much in the substance of the proposal itself. I would like to believe that there is a danger of technological penetration in Europe because of China. But I find this proposal somewhat discriminatory. Indeed, our Parliament has never dealt in the same way with the mass espionage methodically organized, for example, by the United States of America. I remind you of the Echelon case. I recall that the private conversations of the German Chancellor, Mrs Merkel, were spied on, like those of the President of the French Republic. And since then, we have had absolutely no assurance that these practices have ceased, quite the contrary. It seems that the alleged universality of US sanctions law, that the manoeuvring, intimidation, and even the incarceration of European economic leaders continues, and that they have been, as in the case concerning the French company Alstom, a powerful means of blackmail. Then I will be in favour of this proposal on the day when we act in the same way in the face of the risks of espionage of Anglo-Saxon or American origin.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to the requests for Thursday. On Thursday, the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe called for the title of the emergency debate on the situation in Chechnya and the case of Oyub Titiev to be changed to 'The situation in Chechnya', thereby removing the reference to the case of Oyub Titiev.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I wanted to draw your attention to the following. On Thursday, we have an urgency resolution and indeed it is now titled ‘The situation in Chechnya, and the case of Oyub Titiev’. For those who are not aware, he is the director of the human rights and civil society organisation Memorial, an organisation that has won the Sakharov Prize before. The persecution of Mr Titiev is of grave and great concern. It’s very important that we address it. There have been colleagues who have added other important topics to the text. I don’t want to engage in a hierarchy of the gravity of human rights violations, but I do want to draw your attention to the risk of mismatching the title with the substance of the resolution. I think that that could be confusing with negative consequences for all involved and that would defeat our purpose. So, to avoid this kind of confusion and to realign the title and the substance, I would suggest that we simply speak about the situation in Chechnya.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, our political group has asked us to discuss Titiev's situation and we would like to stick to this issue. We are facing a very serious case; it is at the end of a trial in which he was accused, as in totalitarian regimes, of drug possession, simply because he remains in position - I remind you that he is an institution that we have awarded with the Sakharov Prize, memorial, and I do not see why we could not discuss this case and only this case. I do not understand why the other groups want to flood Titiev's case into entirely other issues. So I suggest we stick to this topic.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mrs Harms, I would give you the floor, but since we have to be balanced, with a speech in favour and a speech against, if you intervene, or for or against, then I have to have another person speak. So the debate is becoming incorrect, I do not know whether you want to speak for or against, but I cannot give you the floor on this subject. If it's for other things, very willingly. (Parliament rejected the request) (The order of business was thus established)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the EU Anti—Fraud Programme (COM(2018)0386 – C8—0236/2018 – 2018/0211(COD)) (A8-0064/2019).

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this afternoon's debate concerns the Regulation on the EU Anti-Fraud Programme and is a regulation which pursues two purposes. Firstly, to protect the financial interests of the European Union and, secondly, to promote cooperation and administrative assistance between Member States, and between Member States and the Commission, in the field of customs application and in the field of the fight and application of agricultural rules. This programme is part of the continuity of the Hercules III programme and has been adapted in its financial amount – I hope the Commission can be satisfied – in the context of the current financial perspectives. In this sense, this Programme incorporates two fundamental systems. One of the systems refers to anti-fraud reporting mechanisms, which summarizes the Commission's customs applications, and the other to the administrative complaint correction mechanism with which the Commission assists third countries. It is important to note that this Regulation will enter into force on the first of January 2021 and will not entail an overlap with other programmes in the European Union and, above all, with other programmes which are manifested in the field of combating fraud. I am referring to the OLAF Regulation, I am referring to the Regulation setting up the European Public Prosecutor's Office and I am also referring to the Directive in the field of combating fraud. It is important to stress that the Regulation determines the practical assumptions in which it will be applied — its scope — to avoid these duplications and, at the same time, that the co-financing margin will be a margin of 80%, except in duly justified cases where there are actually financial interests of the European Union that may be affected, in which case the margin may be increased to 90%. I would like to say, Mr President, that, apart from these two objectives, the report we are presenting and the draft Regulation have three other specific objectives which are to prevent and combat fraud, corruption and any other illegal activity affecting the financial interests of the European Union, to support the notification of irregularities, including fraud, with respect to shared management funds and pre-accession assistance funds in the European Union budget , and provide tools for the exchange of information and support for operational activities in the field of mutual administrative assistance. Moreover, with this programme, Parliament considers that it would be very useful if those entities of countries which are united with the Union under partnership agreements could participate in this area of customs cooperation. We have introduced a number of aspects relating to the evaluation, monitoring and control of the Anti-Fraud Programme. We have envisaged that a description of the actions to be financed under this Programme, an indication of the amount allocated, the maximum co-financing rate of subsidies and, in some way, also the obligation to introduce, as already envisaged in the draft Regulation, a report made for the European Parliament and the Council, and a final assessment after the three years. With these initiatives, Mr President, we have somehow wanted to respond to some of the concerns raised by the Court of Auditors in this area. And I would like, in order to conclude this speech, to thank the shadow rapporteurs who have dealt with this report and also the services of the House.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Mr Salafranca, as rapporteur, honourable Members, I am replacing Commissioner Oettinger today, and I am grateful that I can participate in this debate on the proposal for a regulation establishing the EU Anti-Fraud Programme. The Commission and Parliament agree on the paramount importance of protecting the EU financial interests from fraud, corruption and irregularities. These must be effectively and efficiently prevented, detected and tackled at EU and Member State level. The EU institutions have deployed significant efforts to fight against fraud in recent years, for example with the adoption of the new Directive on the protection of the EU financial interests through criminal law (PIF Directive) and the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. The proposed EU Anti-Fraud Programme, despite its relatively small size, fits perfectly into this picture. It combines the longstanding Hercule programme, which has successfully supported the fight against fraud since 2004, with two long-established operational activities performed by the Commission (OLAF – the European Anti-Fraud Office) in the anti-fraud area. The first is the Anti-Fraud Information System, a set of IT tools supporting Member States’ customs authorities in mutual administrative assistance between national authorities and the Commission. The second is the irregularity management system that provides an IT platform for the Member States to report fraud and irregularities affecting the EU budget. The main novelty of the EU Anti-Fraud Programme is to combine these three strands of work, on a single legal basis, in order to provide for synergies and flexibility among them. The Commission wishes to thank Mr Salafranca for his report, which acknowledges the importance and the relevance of the proposal. The Commission takes note of the report’s proposal significantly to increase the financial envelope for the programme, and we interpret that as recognition of the success of the current programme. The amount for the programme will need to be discussed further in the context of the general negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The Commission has chosen to table light-touch basic acts for its proposals for spending programmes in the next MFF cycle in order to achieve a high degree of flexibility, thus allowing the programmes to adapt better to new and unforeseen needs during the seven years of the next MFF. This is why the Commission has chosen, for instance, not to set up co-financing rates for grants in the proposal itself, or to fix only indicative amounts for each of the three pillars of the programme. We ask you to consider carefully the amendments that would deprive the future programme of these elements of flexibility, in particular at a time when there are significant developments in the anti-fraud area, such as the creation of the European Public Prosecutor, which might call for adaptation over time of the activities that the programme supports. This applies also to the adoption of the work programmes, which will become the main tool for programme delivery. These are mere acts of implementation, which do not amend or supplement the legal framework and therefore do not need to be adopted by means of delegated acts. I am confident that the next phase of the procedure will bring Parliament, the Council and the Commission together in a common effort to deliver a new legal act constituting the basis for a modern, flexible, reliable and effective instrument to fight fraud against the EU budget. The Commission wishes to stress that we very much appreciate Parliament’s interest in discussing the results of the Hercule Programme every year. We hope that it will continue this dialogue on the new Anti-Fraud Programme. I thank you for your kind attention and I look forward to a constructive debate.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Mr Salafranca, thank you very much for this work. Today we are dealing with a small but fine programme of only EUR 181 million over seven years. In other words, we cannot have high hopes that we will achieve a great deal there. And, Commissioner, flexibility or not – I do not want 'Hercule' to become a travel programme for all those who work in the fight against fraud and want to exchange occasional exchanges. We are in danger. Personally, I consider the unproposed levels of co-financing to be a mistake. So thank you for writing this in. I believe that we must send out a signal as to how much the European Union is prepared to give the Member States to comply with the European legal framework, the common commitment of what needs to be done at the external border, for example in the customs area. Commissioner! I would like to point out straight away that the Committee on Budgetary Control has dealt at length with what has actually become of the hardware financed in the past. And here it can be said that we are not very good at this long-term monitoring of this hardware – whether the scanners that the EU has purchased for the Member States against tobacco smuggling are ready for use. In other words, it would be beneficial if the Commission had a greater interest in this issue than it has had in the past. I believe that the amendments that have been tabled, namely that we are trying to avoid duplication and to combat the lack of synergies in promoting similar or similar measures, that we need clear added value for this programme and that we need co-financing rates, that the monitoring role of the European Parliament has been strengthened: these are very important things to give this programme efficiency and credibility.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I too would like to thank Mr Salafranca, with whom we have worked very well, for his report, and also to thank him for specifying some of the aspects which we think are fundamental from the point of view of budgetary control. Because, while we understand the Commission's request or proposal for greater flexibility, I would like to ask Commissioner Vella anyway how the Commission understands that the current proposal, as raised by Mr Salafranca, could lead to problems for the future European Public Prosecutor's Office. For our part, it seems to us essential that there be an annual performance report, even though the Programme is small, because it seems to us that there should be no overlaps in the actions of such a programme, there should be no conflicts of interest and, of course, should serve to complement and strengthen other programmes of the same kind to combat fraud. And finally, we are also in favour of doubling the programme budget, but we need you to clarify to us why it seems to you, Mr Vella, that there may be problems with the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I thank Mr Salafranca for a very important report, but I will also say this: this EU anti-fraud programme could, I stress, help to protect financial interests, but we cannot support references to the role of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the PIF Directive as tools to prevent fraud in the European Union, nor to references to the protection of the Union budget in the case of the examination of the rule of law in the Member States. Such references should not be made and they weaken the resolution needed, the report needed. Nor can we accept the dangerous transfer to the European Commission of the powers of the Member States, including when it comes to the application of controls.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, thank you very much. Let us talk today about the most expensive fiasco in the EU, and that is the VAT system, the European VAT system from 1993. That's a gold mine, a gold mine for criminals, crooks and terrorists. Because every year, 50 billion euros, 50 billion euros, goes from taxpayers to these fraudsters. Mr President, that is over a trillion euros in the last 20 years, over 20 years. And that bothers me so much about the EU. The people of the European Union, the citizens, pay themselves blue in taxes and the EU is easily allowed to send that to criminals. The EU must do something about this. And she's not doing it, because she knows she's been in the crosshairs of this problem for a long time.  Mr President, the EU can do it. The Commission can act quickly. The Commission can skip procedures and rules in order to get something done very quickly. She proved that in appointing Mr Selmayr. Thank you very much.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which An EU anti-fraud programme – I find it very regrettable that we need this kind of thing, because we should actually assume that all Member States are careful with EU taxpayers' money. Unfortunately, it is not always the case. It is time and again to stress that EU funding is not a gift, but an investment. If the fight against fraud does not work, then, as I said, that is very regrettable, and unfortunately it is the case with some Member States. It really is time for the Member States to exchange ideas better, to learn from each other and also to make use of the new technological and digital opportunities that we now have.  80% of the EU budget – EUR 125.6 billion in 2017 – is spent by the countries. It is therefore also important to ensure that fraud is dealt with. As an example, Poland received around €10 billion in funding in 2017. The public authorities have just reported one fraud case, private bodies 18.  If you look at these figures, I am actually very much in favour and enthusiastic that we have finally set up such a programme, and we must implement it, and for that we urgently need the support of the Member States. Tax money must be handled with care. We cannot allow ourselves to be negligent under any circumstances. Therefore, thank the rapporteur and thank you for the programme.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: (S&D). – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Eu ropean Union's anti-fraud programme for the period 2021-2027 is particularly important because it aims to finance a number of essential measures for the protection of the Union's financial interests and for combating fraud and corruption.  That is precisely why I believe that, as indicated in the text we are about to vote on, funding should be increased. The Commission's proposal has, moreover, been supplemented and strengthened through the inclusion of provisions aimed at increasing the transparency of work programmes and funding, clarifying the link to the protection of the financial interests that projects must have and ensuring synergies between the various existing financing instruments.  In order to ensure more effective protection of the Union's financial interests, the anti-fraud programme should then be aimed at supporting cooperation between the administrative and law enforcement authorities of the Member States and the relevant Union agencies, including the forthcoming European Public Prosecutor's Office. I would like to thank Mr Salafranca for his work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the programme to combat fraud at European Union level is particularly important and measures should be taken both to prevent fraud and to provide administrative assistance and to make use of the tools available.  We have two levels of fraud: customs operations and — above all — the agricultural sector. I think we should be decisive here. A special — if you will — form of fraud is what we call 'Greekisations' of agricultural products, i.e. foreign products presented as Greek. We import milk from Albania and this is called "Greekized" milk. We have a great import of livestock products from Skopje, which are illegally Greekized. Serious care must be taken and decisive measures must be taken and, of course, the payment of pre-accession aid funds for both Albania and Skopje must be lifted, because they are involved in these customs frauds to the detriment of consumers and to the detriment of the Member States.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Thank you for the floor, President-in-Office. Fraud, corruption and other illegal activities undermine both the financial interests of the European Union and citizens' trust in the rule of law. The anti-fraud programme is important and necessary. European countries lose around €180 billion each year as a result of corruption, of which some estimated €3.5 billion in Slovenia. Value added tax fraud, corruption in health, public procurement and the banking sector are just the tip of the iceberg. We should not be numb to corruption as a society, as if this is something for granted. You have to fight against it at every level of society. Every year in the European Union, we are losing huge amounts of money in drawing on European funds, so just calling for transparency will not be enough if concrete measures do not follow. The European institutions must take a proactive stance so that European safeguards are not so deficient and that the detection of corruption will no longer be left to the will of individual Member States.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the investment of EUR 180 million that the EU has made available to support Member States’ efforts to fight fraud, corruption and other irregularities last March, is a huge step in the right direction. This simply reinforces why each Member State needs each other and how the EU can ensure that we work across borders to root out fraudulent activity. We cannot tackle corruption on our own and that’s why Brexit would cause the UK more untold problems. We would be left at risk of becoming an offshore island for tax havens. We have a fraud epidemic already in the UK costing us GBP 110 billion. The financial cost of fraud in 2018 estimates that the UK economy could be boosted by GBP 44 billion annually if we tackled it fully. And as the OLAF report states, to achieve better results in tackling fraud against the EU’s financial interests the auditors recommend that the Commission should put in place a robust fraud reporting and measurement system providing information on the scale, nature and root causes of fraud. We have to continue to protect the people we represent and the values we hold.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, withdrawal of European funds, but also supervision of this process, in several Member States it is proving to be a real challenge so that I absolutely support all efforts that will facilitate the withdrawal of money while making fraud more difficult or completely impossible. In doing so, we should take care not to over-complicate the withdrawal process itself and re-make it more inefficient, as it is in our interest that the funds be used by those to whom they are intended within the time limit provided. Better and more efficient data sharing, training and employee exchange, and any other proposals that facilitate the exchange of best practices without excessive costs and additional administrative burden are a step in the right direction. The unnecessary establishment of new joint bodies with insufficiently well-defined competences would be completely wrong and would cause additional disorder, so I am much more inclined to this solution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think this is a very important topic because, obviously, everybody dislikes and condemns fraud because it means people are getting money under false pretences and those who deserve it are being denied it. People are paying more taxes to help the fraudsters make more money. I commend Commissioner Vella and my colleague, Mr Salafranca, on the proposals here tonight to try to get more cooperation, essentially between the Member States, so that we can come to terms with this terrible affliction. People have quoted massive figures in relation to how much economies are being denied.  I would like to see us, especially in the next Parliament and the next Commission, really setting targets for the reduction of fraud and illegal activity throughout the European Union because every cent that is saved could be given to people who deserve it, and obviously reduce taxes.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, any programme to combat crime, as is the European anti-fraud programme, must focus not only on the coercive side, but, above all, on the prevention side. I am a lawyer and I know that coercive, post-offence sanctions measures have little effectiveness in preventing crime and are being implemented at much higher costs than prevention itself. In my opinion, an anti-fraud programme must start with concrete preventive measures, including measures to inform European citizens about the different situations in which they may be subject to the law. We still have a lot to do on the preventive side both in the fight against fraud at European level and in the fight against other crimes affecting the European Union budget year after year. That is why I welcome the amendments to the proposals stressing the need for prevention in the fight against fraud, as well as the amendments on increasing the budget for this programme.

text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent This is a good report, although I will say right away that the amendments tabled were both towards correcting it and spoiling it. name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for sharing their views on this important topic. They are clear evidence of the continued support of the Parliament for the fight against fraud and the protection of the EU’s financial interests.  With regard to overlaps with other EU programmes, this programme is the only one specifically supporting the fight against fraud to the EU budget and, as such, does not overlap with the scope of any other programmes such as in the areas of justice and home affairs and customs. In addition, the periodical preparation of the work programmes, through appropriate inter—service consultations, will provide ample opportunity to explore synergies and detect possible overlaps. Furthermore, the Anti-Fraud Programme pursues a different objective from the customs control equipment instrument. The Anti-Fraud Programme specifically aims at the protection of the EU financial interests and therefore covers not only the revenue side, but also the expenditure side through a range of activities, of which financing the acquisition of equipment is only one aspect.  The Commission will ensure that there is no duplication between the programmes during the implementation phase, in particular when establishing the work programmes, which will be done in close consultation with the other Commission services concerned. As regards co—financing rates, the financial regulation no longer requires that co—financing rates are defined in the basic acts. Therefore, the proposal does not fix such rates, in order to provide the programme with the maximum flexibility. This is a horizontal issue across proposals. All your remarks and the amendments that you decide to put forward in the vote tomorrow will be carefully considered for discussion during the next phase of the procedure. Some of them touch cross-cutting issues common to all proposals for spending programmes and will be part of the general negotiations for the next MFF.  The Commission remains fully committed to ensuring that the EU anti-fraud strategy is supported by a modern and flexible financial instrument capable of facing, promptly and effectively, the challenges of future years. In this vein, we look forward to supporting the negotiations between Parliament and the Council with a constructive and cooperative spirit.

name: Alain CADEC
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, the Common Fisheries Policy, revised in 2013, has introduced a new method of fisheries management, namely regionalisation. Regionalisation is the cornerstone of the common fisheries policy. It allows for a programmed management of fisheries in accordance with the specifics of the different basins of the Union. Indeed, measures that work in the Baltic Sea will not have the same effects in the Mediterranean and vice versa. These geographical characteristics must therefore be taken into account. For this reason, we are gradually putting in place multi-year management plans for each basin. Two management plans have already been adopted, for the Baltic Sea and the North Sea. The plan for western waters is therefore the third plan on which the co-legislators have agreed. The plan includes 34 stocks operated by at least seven EU Member States, operating in waters from the west of Scotland to the waters around Madeira and the Azores, via the English Channel, the Celtic Sea and the Bay of Biscay. The range is therefore considerable. Among these stocks, we can now, and thanks to the majority vote of Parliament last October, count the bar. The bar is a popular species not only for professionals, but also for recreational fishers. It is also a species whose stock is in decline. Emergency measures are put in place each year to regenerate the resource. As these annual measures did not provide the necessary visibility for both professional and recreational fishers, it was time to address them. Including this species in a management plan is therefore an essential step towards the sustainable management of this stock. For this reason, I welcome both Parliament's vote and the agreement with the Council. I am also very pleased, because of the end of the artificial delimitation of the 48th parallel for bar fishing. This limit was simply absurd for both professional and recreational fishers. We cannot continue to impose different management measures north and south of this parallel, it does not take into account the realities on the ground. Other species are also covered by this plan, fortunately, sea bream, cod, sole or even the yellow place. For all these stocks, we will now have sustainable and programmed management, providing greater predictability to the fishing sector. The TACs and quotas negotiated annually by the Council for Western Waters are now regulated to avoid drastic quota cuts. This plan is also of particular importance in the context of Brexit. Indeed, British waters, such as the English Channel, are directly affected by this plan. Therefore, with the adoption of this plan before the UK leaves the European Union, it will be part of the Community's achievements during the transition period and will lay the foundations for future fisheries cooperation with the United Kingdom. I am now, of course, waiting for the comments of my fellow Members, as well as the Council and the Commission, and I thank them in advance for their contribution.

name: Alain CADEC
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I will start by warmly thanking the rapporteur, Mr Alain Cadec, the shadow rapporteurs and all those who were involved, for their excellent work and efforts to bring this very important file to a successful conclusion. The agreement which was reached between the co-legislators is a very good result and I want to thank you, Alain, for working tirelessly to ensure a solid and sustainable result that can work in practice. I also want to thank you for ensuring a timely adoption, as you mentioned, ahead of the UK withdrawal from the European Union. The Baltic Sea and the North Sea plans are the blueprints for the Western Waters Plan but, where it was necessary to reflect regional specificities, the co-legislators wisely agreed to find new approaches by addressing, for example, issues linked to recreational fisheries. The Western Waters Plan completes the set of multiannual plans on the Atlantic side of the Union’s waters. It continues on the path of regionalisation, allowing Member States to submit joint recommendations, for example on discard plans, to implement the landing obligations. With this new Plan we ensure that fishermen have the necessary tools for sustainable fishing practices, for example, by adapting their gear to fish more selectively. It is now for the stakeholders of the Western Waters to put these tools into practice and to ensure tailor-made solutions to specific challenges in the different fisheries of the Western Waters. I am happy to see that with this new plan, we are clearly going in the right direction, towards sustainable fisheries, and I am grateful for the support in this House.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, dear Commissioner, from the Anti-Fraud Programme to the multi-year plan, which we like even more. This multiannual plan, of course, aims to ensure that stocks are sustainably exploited and that management is based on the most up-to-date scientific information. And the focus of this plan—as has already been said—is the same as that of the North Sea, the Baltic Sea and the recently approved one for the Mediterranean. The multiannual approach will enable long-term planning of fisheries resource management, avoiding sharp fluctuations in fishing opportunities, while providing greater legal certainty for operators to better plan their businesses. It also allows for greater participation of local fishermen and offers tailor-made measures by basins and fisheries. It also allows you to move away from the micromanagement of Brussels, something that has always been criticized. The objective of achieving population exploitation that respects the principle of maximum sustainable yield is something that is also confirmed. And with regard to recreational fishing, which can have a major impact on stock mortality, it was agreed that the Council will be able to take appropriate measures if necessary. On the other hand, Member States will take measures for the monitoring and collection of data, which is important, as there is often no real estimate of the catch levels of this fisheries. Finally, highlight the relationship between the regulation of technical measures, which I hope that very soon - the day after tomorrow – we will be able to reach an agreement by the Commission, the Council and Parliament, and the multiannual plans. It is very clear: the Technical Measures Regulation should be the framework for all rules on how, when and where fishing can be fished.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, a special greeting to our Commissioner Karmenu Vella and I would like to congratulate Mr Cadec and all those involved in the work carried out during the negotiations. I think so, we got a good end result.  First, because it was ensured the maintenance of one of the most ambitious objectives of the CFP, that is, it remained registered to achieve the maximum sustainable yield by 2020. I know that in some cases this is an ambitious objective and that there is still a long way to go, but we have maintained this ambition under the Regulation. Secondly, because we have included improvements in the protection of sensitive species, resources and important habitats, in particular through the possibility of definite areas of protection for juveniles and for the recovery of springs.  Regionalisation and management proximity, recommended in multiannual plans such as this one, are a solution that has already proven. An example of this is the case of goraz in the Azores, for which several specific management measures were established, resulting from technical measures implemented. The most up-to-date scientific data shows that this feature has been reamy. The regional plan established together with the fishermen allowed positive results, both in the recovery of the species and in the financial benefits obtained. The measures also involved the establishment of Marine Protected Areas and fishing reserves. This management tool is unavoidable and must be multiplied. Finally, these plans will have to contribute to landing obligations, but we have to allow exceptions: individuals fished below the minimum size and who have proven relevant survival rates should be returned to the sea. Bringing to land fished without interest and that, surviving, can reproduce and later be caught with greater economic benefit is doubly positive. I therefore highlight in particular the exception created for the fishing of goraz and berix in the western waters of the Atlantic.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear Chairman, the regional approach to the regulation of fishing efforts ensures that each sea basin will be approached taking into account its specificities. That's the kind of approach I've called for from day one, and I can only support it. This is extremely important if we want good regulation that will not be discriminatory and put fishermen from individual regions in a worse position on the market. When we discussed the Adriatic, my position as rapporteur was that we do not need universal solutions that will blindly favor industry or environmental activists, but sustainable regulation based on proven solutions and scientific research.  I support the same approach when it comes to western waters. I consider the possibility of scientific advice to propose changes in regulation to the Commission in accordance with the real state of fish stocks as a real step forward that will ensure quality solutions in the future.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the success of multiannual fisheries plans in the Union is based on the seriousness of the scientific data supporting the decisions taken and the coherence with which they are applied on fishing areas and species. And only in this way does the concept of "maximum sustainable performance" make sense. Only in this way can fleets benefit from the stability offered by predictable medium-term quotas. That is why this plan, as it reaches the Plenary, is a step forward on the previous situation, but it still presents weaknesses. We insist on three issues in order to eliminate them. First, better define the concept of "best available scientific data". We should only consider studies carried out using transparent working methods and a certification of neutrality by solvent technical authorities to be valid. Secondly, to strengthen the guarantees that professionals should enjoy in the face of catches of high-value species by recreational fishing enthusiasts. The weight of recreational catches on populations must be weighed and any competition in the market between professional and recreational catches should be avoided. Thirdly, empower the European Commission to act when national authorities do not exercise the responsibilities and powers offered to them by this Regulation under regionalisation. Adapting basic principles to specific situations should not be confused with shether to stop applying them. Finally, we are pleased that the possibility that the Council may suspend, albeit briefly and for exceptional reasons, the bans on catches decreed to recover a species has been eliminated. Opening that possibility makes the saying "Bread for today, hunger for tomorrow" a reality. And when it came to fishing stocks, "hunger for tomorrow" means hunger forever. And I would like to thank Mr Cadec and the rest of the rapporteurs for the work done together.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, without jeopardising the usefulness of medium-term instruments for fisheries management, as is the case with multiannual plans, in order to ensure some predictability, stability and sustainability for the sector, going beyond the contingencies associated with the annual distribution of TACs and quotas, the truth is that these plans have not called into question the essentials of an overly centralised management model, far from reality, which does not take into account the diversity of situations that characterise the fisheries sector, in particular in the case of small-scale and artisanal fisheries, and the specificities of each country. As far as the specific case of this plan is the case of some positive developments in the negotiations on certain aspects, we would stress at the close of this case that the European Commission did not, it remained ungiven, to give the convincing answer to the option by apparently yielding to pressure so far to join two distinct realities, both in terms of resources and fisheries exploiting those resources, such as the realities of the western waters north and south.

text: – Mr President, while Donald Tusk may be praying for a special hell for Brexiteers, what he refuses to realise is that many in the EU are already there. name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, after the last speech I will come back to normality. The agreement that was recently reached on the multiannual plan for fish stocks in the western waters and adjacent waters is an important one. Not only because it has proven difficult to find agreement on such plans in the past, but because it is a strong agreement that will help to ensure the sustainable exploitation of stocks in Belgian, German, French, Irish, Spanish, Portuguese and, yes, United Kingdom waters. We are all aware of the challenges faced by the fishing sector in the western waters. Fishers in my constituency in the southern coast of Ireland face significant challenges due to the obligations of our fisheries policies targeting specific species in this region. It is difficult due to catches being mixed and this, combined with the landing obligation and inability to discard catches, makes life difficult. I am pleased, therefore, to see this agreement incorporate all relevant stocks into a single management plan, replacing the existing single species which would allow for some flexibility for fisheries. Sustainable stocks are vital and that’s what we have to include. Finally, I welcome the agreement on recreational fisheries. Any restrictions on recreational fishing should be based on scientific evidence and objective criteria. This is a welcome inclusion in the agreement. I congratulate ‘mon ami’ Mr Cadec and the Commissioner, Mr Vella.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, first of all, can I commend the rapporteur for his work on this proposal, especially the strong emphasis on a science-based framework of the proposal. I have always been a strong proponent of the use of scientific evidence when formulating policy. Independent science-led policy-making has and continues to be the most effective approach. The proposal also seeks to move closer to a policy of regionalisation. This frankly makes sense rather than adopting a blanket approach. Regionalisation has the benefit of delivering specific regulation for specific sea basins. As the UK prepares for its departure from the EU, it is vital we ensure a strong foundation for future cooperation. In this case I welcome the focus on the sustainable management of shared stocks. While there is still much uncertainty surrounding and regarding Brexit, for the fishing communities in my constituency of Northern Ireland, I am hopeful that this proposal would at least deliver some degree of certainty for them.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Cadec, for his good work, and to highlight the speed with which this very important Western water plan has been approved. I will repeat an idea that is known and shared by many: I would have liked that there would have been two plans for western waters, one for the north and one for the south, because they are very different areas. And there is another point which I would like to underline and which I repeated in the Committee on Fisheries: I have not supported the inclusion in the Bass Plan. name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of you for your interventions and valuable views, and also for the broad support for this multiannual plan. I have taken due note of the various points raised during this debate. But let me reiterate, it is of utmost importance that the multiannual plans are made straightaway fit for purpose. To ensure this, they need to provide the tools to ensure a practical and sustainable management framework for our mixed demersal fisheries. The co-legislators have achieved this with the Western Waters Plan. It was not only important to have a multiannual plan in place for the Western Waters but also to have the multiannual plan as soon as possible. This is the way to implement the regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which is an important feature of the latest CFP reform in 2013. It provides a tool to facilitate reaching the maximum sustainable yield (MSY) objective by defining ranges of fishing opportunities in line with MSY. This provides the necessary flexibility to reduce potential choke problems. With the 2020 deadline approaching, it is important to have this possibility in place as soon as possible. It also allows Member States to recommend, via joint recommendations, appropriate technical measures to improve the conservation of the stocks, to facilitate the landing obligations and to protect juveniles.

name: Alain CADEC
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would first like to thank my colleagues for their contribution to this debate. I also thank, of course, the Council and the Commission, dear Karmenu, for the work we have done together. With regard to the intervention of our UKIP colleague, who has indeed left the Chamber, I would say that what is excessive is insignificant. In any case, to get back to our question, we need to get to sustainable fisheries management as quickly as possible. I am sure that the management plans will enable us to achieve our sustainability and selectivity objectives in the most appropriate way.  As you have said, Commissioner, and I would remind you that the maximum sustainable yield must be achieved, for all stocks, in 2020. This is why management plans will obviously be useful. However, it has taken us too long, far too long, to put them in place, and now the goal of sustainable maximum return in 2020 seems difficult to achieve, it must be said. On the other hand, we sometimes have to get out of political dogma to correspond to the realities on the ground, I am obviously thinking of our colleagues in the Greens, for example. This is also the case with the landing obligation, which, as we had foreseen, is almost impossible for multi-specific fleets. Having said that, the multi-year management plan for western waters is the result of a delicate balance, always the same, between the protection of the resource, which is indispensable, and the economic competitiveness of the fishing sector, which we want. Anyway, we can collectively be proud of the work we have done, I think that is something interesting. Now let's continue with the Mediterranean.
