name: João FERREIRA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, the objective of the protocol implementing the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Côte d'Ivoire, now renewed for a period of six years, is to provide fishing opportunities for vessels from Member States of the European Union in the waters of Côte d'Ivoire, on the basis of the best available scientific advice and compliance with the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. This protocol is expected to enable the European Union and the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire to work more closely together to promote the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in The Waters of Côte d'Ivoire and to support the country's efforts to develop the local economy from the contribution made by the fisheries sector. In good time, the Committee on Fisheries, by my proposal, understood that it would carry out a more detailed assessment and consideration of this agreement, its history and future prospects, making considerations and recommendations which is now expected that the European Commission will take into account during the duration of the Protocol and its possible future renegotiation. The first fisheries agreement between Côte d'Ivoire and the European Community dates back to 1990. Despite the fact that 28 years, almost 29 years have passed, the results obtained so far in the field of sectoral cooperation are clamorously scarce. This is a reality that needs to be changed. The agreement should promote effective sustainable development of the Ivorian fisheries sector, as well as related industries and activities by increasing the added value in the country as a result of the exploitation of its natural resources. Better coordination is needed between sectoral support under the fisheries agreement and the instruments available in development cooperation, in particular the European Development Fund through both its national programming and regional programming within the West Africa region. The European Commission should take the necessary measures, including the possible revision and increase of the sector support agreement component, alongside improving the conditions for increasing the absorption rate of this support in order to ensure an effective reversal of the path taken in recent decades. As with other countries in the region, it is considered necessary to improve the quantity and reliability of catch information and in general on the state of conservation of fisheries resources, alongside the development of Ivory Coast's own capacity for acquiring this information. I can only thank the shadow rapporteurs for their work and the attention they have given to these reports and stress that Parliament must be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures relating to the protocol or its renewal. In particular, we propose that the European Commission report annually on the results of the multiannual sectoral programme and on compliance with the requirement for the declaration of catches.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as Mr Ferreira mentioned, the EU and the Ivory Coast have a longstanding relationship in fisheries. The renewal of the Protocol to the Sustainable Fishing Partnership Agreement will further strengthen this relationship. Through this partnership, the Ivory Coast not only offers access to its waters to EU vessels, but it also processes the products stemming from these vessels’ fishing activities and further exports them to the EU. This partnership will also help improve the sustainability of the fisheries sector, in particular through fighting illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. Combating IUU fishing is a priority for both the European Union and the Ivory Coast as IUU fishing threatens the natural resources and lives of local fishermen depending on them. This will reinforce the ongoing collaboration with the West Africa regional bodies and the European Fisheries Control Agency on monitoring, control and surveillance operations funded by PESCAO regional development programmes. This new six—year Protocol provides increased funds to support the Ivory Coast’s fisheries policy. It will contribute to the establishment of a meaningful surveillance capacity and improved governance, and it will also support the development of the blue economy, inland aquatic resources and artisanal fisheries. We have placed special emphasis on the benefits for local operators as Abidjan is a major port in the region. Indeed, the EU tuna fleet operating off the coast of Western Africa lands a great part of the catches in Abidjan to supply local canneries. This supports employment locally in the canneries, but also on board EU vessels as Ivorian seamen are in the first rank of non—EU nationals employed. Landings of EU vessels are also supporting the activities of small—scale economic operators. I would like to mention here the association of women organised to collect and transform such resources for local use. They have clearly expressed their needs for a supply from our vessels’ landings so that they could make a decent living from their activities. The Commission is engaged in a dialogue with the industry to ensure that landings become a regular source of revenue for these women, as it is our conviction that EU industrial activities also need to benefit local small operators. I look forward to your remarks and trust that you will support the renewal of the Protocol to this important Sustainable Fisheries Agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, dear Commissioner, this Agreement is one of the most important for the Community tuna fleet in the Atlantic Ocean, and the port of Abidyan is practically the only operational port in the area. Tuna seedlings use it both for their transfer and sales operations to the country's canneries and for supplies and crew change, embarking a large number of sailors of this nationality. But above all, the sustainable fisheries agreements concluded by the European Union with third countries are, as the name suggests, a unique tool available to the European Union to increase fisheries cooperation with third countries by promoting a sustainable fisheries policy and also sustainable exploitation of fishery resources outside the waters of the European Union. And this is in everyone's interest. It is good for operators in the European Union, it is good for local development, for combating illegal fishing, for sustainability and for good governance of the oceans. In parts of the world where there are no agreements with the European Union, there are often fleets that do not respect fishing resources or the marine environment. Neither the social conditions of workers nor sustainability. These fleets compete directly with our European Union operators and often catch the same fish and sell them to the same markets, but at much lower prices. For this reason, maintaining such agreements is vital. The European Union's long agreement with Ivory Coast has been helping Ivory Coast, the Ivory Coast economy, local fishermen, also the use of Abidyan harbour facilities, and, of course, the canneries. That is why we must ratify this Agreement as soon as possible. And I thank, logically, the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Ferreira for his report on this important agreement. This is an important step forward for fisheries cooperation and should help to promote sustainable fisheries and sustainable development of the Ivorian fisheries sector. The support offered will help Côte d’Ivoire to develop its blue economy, improve safety on board, improve fishermen’s income and enable fish markets to be built. The commitment by Côte d’Ivoire to increase capacity for monitoring, control and surveillance is also an important step in combating illegal unreported and unregulated fishing in the region and improving scientific knowledge. Given the importance of workers’ rights for my group, I am particularly pleased to see that there is a progressive agreement here which focuses on improving working conditions, especially for women. It will also facilitate the involvement of trade unions and artisanal fishermen’s associations in the region, setting a good example for other fisheries agreements. On the EU side, it’s also an advantageous agreement, which will allow us regulated access to Ivorian waters.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There are many reasons to support this report. Firstly, the mutual benefits for the development of both Côte d'Ivoire's fishing fleet and the economic benefits for the fleet of european Union countries. Secondly , and most importantly, it is a prudent and sustainable exploitation of marine resources based on available scientific advice and taking into account the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas. After all, bluefin tuna, for example, is one of the most valuable fish in the world and these fish species must be protected from over-normative fishing. Illegal fishing should be combated, tuna fishing techniques controlled and supervised, and the likelihood of dolphin catches, which are usually near tuna shoals, should be reduced. It is therefore our duty to protect the marine ecosystem, precious fish stocks and biodiversity for future generations, but also to support other countries, including Côte d'Ivoire.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the fisheries agreements between Europe and third countries have shown that they are a fundamental tool for extending around the world the environmental and social standards that apply to the sector in Community waters. In addition, they induce development in the countries with which they sign and offer fishing opportunities to our professionals. In this case, thirty-six tuna sewn-up boats from Spain, France and Portugal will fish under this agreement which will be in force until 2024; a key agreement for the Basque tuna fleet, whose ships also have been in place with independent certifications of good environmental and social practices since 2010, when they were recognized as "friends of the sea". As mentioned, the economic contributions to the agreement will be offset by Ivory Coast on the one hand by catches, but most of the resources go to the development of the local fisheries sector. In this chapter a central element is the support for the operations of the port of Abidán, affected at the time by the Council's sanctions against the Laurent Gbagbo regime. The promotion of local professionals and businesses is completed by a commitment to the quality of scientific studies on fishing stocks, the establishment of biologically protected fishing areas and the strengthening of undeclared, unregulated and unregulated anti-fishing control measures.  I also underline the commitment to improving the position and working conditions of women in the local artisanal fisheries sector dedicated to fish smoking and the promotion of women's professional organizations as a guarantee of sustainability and development of the area.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As in most West African countries, fish is the main source of protein for the people of Côte d'Ivoire. Competition with industrial vessels and oil extraction limits the opportunities of small-scale fishing. Women working in the sector only have access to fish for four months of the year. The rest of the time they have to buy imported fish, landed in the port of Abidjan, which is sold by intermediaries whose sole goal is to squeeze out as high a profit as possible. Cheap, good quality raw materials are hard to come by. But there are so-called fake tuna landed by European vessels. It's damaged tuna that's not used in the canneries. With the new agreement, the local market will have access to 10 000 tonnes of counterfeit tuna. It is a top priority for women's cooperatives to have access to this fish rather than accessing the intermediaries who drive up prices. The issue of fish for women in West Africa may seem a small part of this. But this is very, very important for building local resilience in Côte d'Ivoire.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, this agreement belongs to the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa, to which agreements with Guinea-Bissau, Cape Verde and Sao Tome and Principe also belong, among others. It is an agreement of great geographical relevance.  The port of Abidjan is one of the main ports in West Africa, either by the landings there or by the volume of fish processing. Its importance, in particular for tuna, demonstrates the relevance of this agreement for Union fisheries, considering that part of that fish ends up being destined for this market.  I end by stressing my support for the agreement, stressing the need to ensure that the associated funds actually revert to the development of the socio-economic sector of the blue economy of Côte d'Ivoire, but also to the control of the activity, in particular to ensure that the fish marketed and processed in the port of Abidjan does not come from IUU fishing.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, in the end, I think we all want the same thing –that’s responsible and sustainable fishing. This is also the case in this new protocol. As such, it provides for close collaboration to promote the sustainable exploitation of fishing resources in those waters, and it also supports the efforts of the country to develop the blue economy, in the interests of both us and them. On one side, the Ivorian fishing industry, in particular the small-scale fisheries, need structural support from the EU to contribute more effectively to national development and food needs. On the other hand, the evaluation of the previous protocol concluded that a renewal of the protocol would help strengthen monitoring, control and surveillance and contribute to improving governance of fisheries in the region. This is a win-win situation and tomorrow we should vote in favour and give consent to the conclusion of this protocol.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is my last activity today. I would like to draw attention to only one important point. On the one hand, the adoption of the text of this protocol is not in doubt, but please note one important, really important dispute that we have at the political level. It concerns, above all, a conflict, a certain dispute between the text of the resolution itself and the proposal for an agreement. I am interested in the source of such opposition, such a conflict, which ultimately, however, undermines parliament's authority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Union's fisheries agreement protocol with Côte d'Ivoire must be implemented on the basis of mutual benefit. Not only do the 36 fishing boats from France, Spain and Portugal win, but they should also earn — of course — the local populations. On this basis, measures should be taken to support the local population and, of course, improve the status of women. I think that the measures taken, as well as the measures related to labour legislation, are important. I think it is extremely important that support is also provided for the training of fishermen and seafarers. Interventions to support small local producers are also in the right direction and the protocol as a whole can contribute to the development of the blue economy, to maritime safety and — of course — to the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you honourable Members. As requested by the rapporteur, the sectoral support will be largely increased to over EUR 400 000. That’s almost an increase of some 35% to support local development and improved governance of fisheries. Also, the Commission will keep the Parliament regularly informed of the implementation of this agreement and will also provide reports both on the catches and on the use of the EU financial contributions. The conclusion of the new Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement will reinforce the stable relationship between the EU and Côte d’Ivoire for mutually beneficial outcomes. This new Protocol is fully consistent with the EU’s ocean governance agenda, under which the Union cooperates with third countries with the purpose of improving compliance with international measures, including combating illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing (IUU). To conclude I would like to thank the speakers for their comments, for their support for this Protocol and especially the rapporteur, Mr Ferreira, for his report.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the various speeches and, finally, to highlight one of the points of the resolution that we will be voting on tomorrow: the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Côte d'Ivoire, implementation and possible revisions and/or renewals, it shall take into account and be aligned with the relevant strategic plans fully respecting the sovereignty of Côte d'Ivoire, with a view to the development of the Ivorian fisheries sector, in particular by strengthening controls and surveillance of the exclusive economic zone of Côte d'Ivoire and measures to combat unreported and unregulated illegal fishing, support for the construction and/or rehabilitation of fish markets, landing docks and ports , in particular, but not only, with regard to the port of Abidjan, of improving working conditions in the sector, including women's working conditions, in particular in smoking, enabling a more effective conservation system, support for vocational training and strengthening scientific research capacity and monitoring of fisheries resources, support for organisations representing men and women in fisheries, especially those linked to artisanal fishing, and the overall improvement of the sustainability of maritime resources. Finally, we call on the European Commission to provide information on the benefits that the implementation of the Protocol will bring to local economies in terms of employment, infrastructure, improved social conditions, as well as on catches and the state of conservation of resources, so that we can better assess the impact of the agreement on the marine ecosystem and fishing communities.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, during this parliamentary term the Committee on Constitutional Affairs has continued to work on how to improve the current institutional regulatory framework, our rules of play. That is why we have produced a significant number of reports on the application of the rules governing our institutions. We are ripe for the final momentum on those issues that we have found particularly relevant. In my case, I have had the honour of being the rapporteur of the report on the implementation of the provisions of the Treaty relating to citizenship of the Union, at a time as key as the one we are experiencing. "Collective public policies are the only thing that can create citizens with the confidence of individuals," says Timothy Snyder in his latest book. The concept of Citizenship of the Union has been introduced for more than twenty years, and today at least one generation of Europeans has grown up as Community citizens. And a generation of children need adjustments and improvements to the concept of European citizenship by the time they are, in a short time, our young Europeans. The Treaties say that it is a citizen of the European Union who has the nationality of one of its Member States. In this way, citizenship of the Union is in addition to state citizenship. However, the law has fallen short of reality. About what young people and children already perceive. We have a responsibility to take on the results that European barometers reveal to us over and over again. 87% of Europeans are aware of their status as citizens – the highest percentage ever recorded. But between what they perceive and reality there is a mismatch. There are gaps, there is a deficit and there is a need to give real scope to some of these freedoms. Union citizens do not exercise the right of active and passive suffrage in European and municipal elections as much as they could. Most of them need more information. And exercising their active citizenship, politics, is key to building much more inclusive, more prosperous, more responsible societies, with fewer risks of temptations to exclusionary populism. Nationalist and populist ideologies promote exclusionary identities; once again we know in Europe. And, on the horizon, this always brings a decline in rights. They give false solutions to real and complex problems, and feed on the spread of victimism. Our responsibility is to make improvements that make solutions, and that also provide solutions in improving what this European citizenship means. Freedom of movement is now enshrined, but has limits on implementation. Pointing out this circumstance is the first step in completing this freedom, which should be enjoyed, especially, by the younger ones. In this context, effectively enhancing programmes such as Erasmus+, programmes for volunteering, such as the European Voluntary Service and the European Solidarity Corps, fuel mobility opportunities. The educational and personal development of young Europeans is undoubtedly the best investment. An investment that comes out very profitable. This report also is committed to the development of 165 curriculum in education systems that allow us to know our common space, our European values, from Article 165 of the Treaty on Functioning. No policy has created as much a sense of Europeans as mobility and education. When knowledge is capitalized it always leads to a natural and spontaneous increase in the link between institutions and citizens. Commissioner Timmermans has told us many times through his own personal experiences. Okay, I'm going to finish. We have studied the full potential of Europe Direct options and the scope of rights and obligations to give them a greater chance to encourage participation. But there's something, there's something, to finish, that's very important. We need symbols. We need to follow luxembourg's example and set as a public holiday for the whole of Europe on 9 May. And we can ask the European Council to speak out for the Heads of State and Government to declare it festive. And, moreover, there are many issues on which we can reach full potential. A european Union citizenship status would be a novel instrument for this. That is why in this report we wanted to change the perspective and place citizens at the heart of the system for the future: citizenship, not an algorithm.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, we have had the opportunity to make this point on several occasions, the Lisbon Treaty is a fairly underutilized toolkit and among the possible procedures - and which are not being used sufficiently - are enhanced cooperation. As we know, enhanced cooperation is a formula that allows countries that want to move forward, while others would be more reluctant, to act, to move forward without waiting for others, in simplified procedures, in areas important to them and for Europe and which fall under shared competences between the Union and the Member States. However, it turns out that many of the major challenges facing the Union today will be difficult to deal with the crippling procedure of unanimity. I am talking about internal and external security, migration policy, a number of social programmes, a number of research programmes and a common foreign policy. It is therefore important to facilitate and encourage the use of this procedure. That is the purpose of the report adopted by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. And we start from the acquis of the strengthened cooperations already existing and which show their interest because they apply to completely different areas: the settlement of divorce or family property disputes, the establishment of a single European patent, the establishment of a European prosecutor, projects that are difficult to commit to a financial transaction tax, the launch of a European defence, not to mention the organisation of the euro area. , which is also part of a form of enhanced cooperation. Our committee's implementation report draws lessons from these early experiences and proposes a kind of what could be a model status of enhanced cooperation to facilitate the task and save time for Member States which, in new areas, would like to use it. And we list the political questions to be asked: what is the decision-making process going to be? Of course, we recommend what the treaty makes possible, namely the systematic use of qualified majority voting and not the unanimous decision. What secretariat? We want the European Commission to have an important role in the secretariat. What is the financing method for administrative expenses, possibly operational expenses, if joint actions are planned? What democratic control? The European Parliament must play an important role, but in some areas it would be unimaginable if there would not also be representation of national parliaments to ensure parliamentary control. And then what judicial review? Of course, while the Court of Justice will always have the final say, it may be useful in some cases to establish - it has been done for patents - a trial court. Our committee recommends respecting the spirit of the treaties, which allow for joint action, allow for flexibility in decision-making and allow us to remain within the Community framework. Because according to enhanced cooperation, the Member States participating do so within the Community framework, while the other non-participating Member States can take part in the debate, give their opinion and - of course - they do not take part in the vote. But being associated from the beginning, they can better measure the value of the formula and it is hoped that, little by little, this cooperation will extend to all the Member States of the European Union. The issue is very important because if we want to tackle these major challenges that I mentioned earlier, there are only two solutions: either enhanced cooperation within the framework of the Union, or interstate, inter-governmental agreements that will make problems more difficult, procedures more obscure and democratic control less well assured.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, parliamentary control of the executive is a precondition for the democratic legitimacy of the executive itself. Recent changes in legislative procedures and the increased role of the Community executive have created the need to strengthen parliament's control procedures.  As you know, Parliament has at its disposal various instruments for exercising its political control over the Commission: from the election of the President, to the investiture of Commissioners, to the motion of censure, to written and oral questions, to legislative initiative, albeit indirectly, through reports, to the budgetary procedure and to the implementation of the budget, etc. However, it is necessary to improve their application and adapt them to the specific challenges of the Union's institutional structure.  After an in-depth study of the situation, which involved many experts and lasted more than six months, the important points of this report are summarised. Firstly, the proposal to lower the threshold for triggering the motion of censure. We believe that the current threshold is too high to allow it to be used effectively, although of course it must not be too low to prevent abuse either. We therefore propose, in a forthcoming amendment to the Treaties – because the Treaties need to be amended – that it be lowered, probably around an absolute majority, but it will be part of the debate.  Within the framework of the current Treaties – my second point – Parliament does not formally have the right of legislative initiative. The report states the possibility of formally granting Parliament this initiative, which should also obviously be sown in the next amendment of the Treaties, again taking into account the specific problems, the specific issues, which may concern this Parliament, therefore not by attributing it to the individual Member but to larger aggregations.  Another point is the individual responsibility of commissioners. The report considers that a future amendment to the Treaties should consider making Commissioners individually responsible for the exercise of their mandate before Parliament.  Another point is the appointment of senior Commission officials. The report calls on the Commission to review its administrative procedures for the appointment of its Secretary-General, Directors-General and Directors, to ensure that the best candidates are selected transparently and that all the same opportunities are ensured. As you will have understood, this report, which is also an overview of political control over the Commission, also contains a number of political messages. The first is the guarantee of an effective system of counter-power in the Union's institutional area. Secondly, the strengthening of our controls on the appointment of senior officials who have a political role in the Commission. Thirdly, the politicisation of the Commission through the Spitzenkandidat process, to which we support it, does, however, involve greater and more individual control of the Commissioners. And finally: a formal allocation of the legislative initiative to our Parliament.  I would like to conclude by thanking my shadow rapporteurs for their excellent spirit of cooperation with which they have worked and hoping that tomorrow, also taking into account the many compromises we have reached, the vote will be broadly positive and shared.  This vote tomorrow will not be the only one. That is why, on behalf of my group, I should like to say something about the other reports on which we shall be voting tomorrow. First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleagues Mr Spinelli and Mr Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz on the Lamassoure report, for which I am shadow rapporteur. I would like to acknowledge the excellent compromise work carried out by the rapporteur. He was particularly good at stressing the need to make the use of enhanced cooperation more flexible. These are a fundamental instrument for improving the construction of Europe, where we cannot find a compromise that brings together the 28 Member States.  Mr President, I understand that I have six minutes, which is why I was going ahead quietly.

name: Mercedes BRESSO

I can only fully support and welcome this idea, because our Parliament is a place of innovation and institutional impetus.  I believe that these reports and the others we are going to discuss, including mr Schöpflin's very interesting report, show how attentive Parliament is to institutional issues, but how little the Council is. I am not saying the Commission, the Commission is always very attentive to our proposals, the Council is much less attentive, and I believe that this is one of the serious democratic problems of our Union.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to explain the basic objectives I have pursued in the long work on the report on the implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  There is one point on which I have stressed in particular, and that is that the Union must not be passive towards the rights enshrined in the Charter, it must not confine itself to preventing any violation of these rights, but must actively promote them, that is to say, their systematic and preliminary amalgamation into all the measures and decisions taken by the Union. This is not only an obligation under international human rights law, but a duty expressly enshrined in the Charter itself.  The Charter has certainly been a turning point in European integration, but its adoption cannot and must not be seen as a final goal. The nature of the Charter is evolutionary, influenced by international law and the case law of the Court. It is the full realisation of the rights enshrined in it that must be constantly sought.  I am not saying this at random, I say this on the basis of the conviction that the crisis in the Union is too wide and that the gap that has been created between citizens and The European institutions is too wide for the situation not to be taken into account, starting with the citizens, their discontent and their feeling that they are being ignored in their rights. In many European policies, the rights listed in the Charter do not have the space that is formally guaranteed to them by European law, as well as by the case law of the Court of Justice. They are often ignored, especially when social rights and the relationship between them and the requirements of competitiveness in the single market are at stake.  The rights of those who, whether irregularly or regularly, enter and reside in the territory of the Union and are therefore part of our legal system are also ignored. Hence my call for systematic impact assessments on rights, both preliminary and ex post, whenever policies are adopted in crucial areas, such as economic stability policies, especially in the eurozone, trade policies and agreements with third countries signed by the Eu ropean Union, migration policy. These issues are partly already present in the report, but which I repeat in some of the amendments for plenary, both on so-called economic governance and on refugees and migrants, whose right to non-refoulement we are called upon to respect by law. The aim of this text is to clarify the role of the Charter, highlighting the difficulties that continue to arise in its full implementation. Stress testing is a tool used to probe banks' resilience; we should also start using similar tests for the maintenance of fundamental rights.  My intention is to provide ideas and proposals which should not be controversial and which can consolidate the solemn promise made to our citizens by adopting the Charter as the Union's legal basis and an indispensable complement to the Treaties. The promise to build a community based on respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the four reports under discussion today present an interesting analysis of the Union’s functioning in connection with citizenship and fundamental rights, whilst providing a contribution to the debate on the Future of the Union on various institutional questions. I cannot, of course, cover every part of these rich reports here this evening. As concerns Ms Bresso’s report, I would like to stress that this College of Commissioners has taken very seriously its political accountability to Parliament. Cooperation between our two institutions is set out in the Framework Agreement and in the Inter-Institutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, which, together with relevant Treaty provisions, provide a framework in which Parliament can effectively exercise its political oversight of the Commission. The Commission considers that these arrangements have worked well and the benefits of our good cooperation, in my view, are clear.  The fact that we have set joint legislative priorities through joint declarations has helped focus political attention on the proposals that matter most in terms of addressing citizens’ concerns and expectations. Good progress has been made, too, on various institutional issues that are priorities for this House. I also welcome the fact that agreement was reached on non-binding delineation criteria for delegated acts and implementing acts, and I hope that tomorrow’s trilogue will result in agreement on the alignment to the Lisbon Treaty of empowerments and the regulatory procedure with scrutiny in approximately 60 legislative acts. As concerns Parliament’s proposal on the right of inquiry, while sharing many of the serious concerns expressed by the Council, the Commission, as always, stands ready to engage constructively and find appropriate solutions. The unanimity rule has, in some cases, hampered effective decision making and timely Union action. The Commission has therefore called for the use of the ‘passerelle clause’ to move to qualified majority voting in certain areas of common foreign and security policy, taxation and the environment. In the taxation area in particular, this would also mean less need for recourse to enhanced cooperation, which is the subject of Mr Lamassoure’s report. I certainly agree with him – and I remember fondly the time we spent working on the Lisbon Treaty – that the Treaty is not being used to its full potential today. Many things are still being ignored or not used to full potential. The Commission welcomes these two reports that actively promote the debate on the Union’s future institutional development. I have to note, however, that treaty change is not currently on the agenda and that many of the ideas would affect the interinstitutional balance or the prerogatives of the other institutions. Turning to Ms Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz’s report on European citizenship: our two institutions have been close allies in promoting and defending European citizens’ rights and the rule of law. I have to say that the rapporteur has always been a staunch supporter of the Commission’s position, and I want to thank her for that, on behalf of the Commission and in a personal capacity. The Commission remains fully committed to the Union’s accession to the European Convention on Human Rights. The consultation process to address the legal issues raised by the Court is making good progress, but is not yet completed. Then, if we resolve that, there remain some issues to be resolved in the Council of Europe as well.  I am grateful that, like the Commission, this Parliament has consistently kept questions of the rule of law high on its agenda, although all of us would have strongly preferred that this had not been necessary. The Commission will present an initiative later this year on strengthening the rule-of-law framework in the light of experience and will take good account of your views in this regard. Many of you have worked very hard on this. The Commission has taken action throughout its term of office to promote the democratic rights of citizens, culminating in the package of proposals in September to enhance transparency, combat disinformation and ensure that individual data is not abused, in the context of the upcoming elections. The recent agreement on the amendments to the statute of European political parties is very welcome indeed. The Commission has also recently published a report on investor citizenship and resident schemes – so-called golden passports and visas – and will set up a group of experts from Member States to improve the transparency, governance and security of such schemes.  Finally, with regard to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, Ms Spinelli’s report is right to point out that, regrettably, the Charter is still not being used to its full potential. Far from it. Upholding common values and fundamental rights is a shared responsibility of local, regional, national, European and international actors and institutions. We all need to work together. The Commission is using a wide range of instruments to ensure the full effectiveness of the Charter. These include infringement proceedings to address values-related violations of EU law by Member States, audits and investigations relating to the use of EU funds, and the European Semester to monitor national justice reforms. We agree with you that, ahead of the elections, all the EU institutions should make an effort to promote the benefits of, and advances made on, European Union citizenship and respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Beyond that, our energies in the coming weeks should be focused on delivering on a positive agenda by securing good outcomes in the pending legislative negotiations. The Commission welcomes the energy and commitment of this Parliament. The Romanian Presidency will continue to engage actively and constructively with you to deliver concrete results across all areas of the 10 priorities of the Juncker Commission, priorities that were established together with you. Together we should show, ahead of the elections, that the Union is able to deliver concrete results and respond to citizens’ expectations.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, I will speak on the subject of the implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the EU institutional framework. Since the Lisbon Treaty entered into force, the Charter is the source of primary law. It is therefore imperative to call on EU bodies to fully comply with the Charter’s provisions. Equal consideration should be given to social and economic rights and Member States need to respect their obligation to the social and economic requirements of the Charter, also when complying with the EU’s economic instruments.  We also need to ensure awareness and promotion of fundamental rights and freedoms and, by extension, of the Charter’s provision. Communication on this must be done at both national and EU level and should be further enhanced. Lastly, we need to recognise and support the role of the Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA) and its recommendations in improving the culture of fundamental rights across the whole EU.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, yet again the British Government is breaching EU citizens’ rights. A provision of the Good Friday Agreement recognises the right of people born in the north of Ireland to be Irish, British or both. Yet the British Government never implemented these provisions, concealing that fact under EU law.  Emma DeSouza, an Irish citizen, has had a legal battle with the British Home Office since 2015. They are refusing her American husband residency. Emma holds an Irish passport, she is an EU right-holder, yet Britain’s Home Office claims she’s British. She is not. Last week, the British Home Office ruled that, post Brexit, Irish citizens born in the north of Ireland will not benefit from retaining EU rights. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I alerted MEPs to Britain’s plot to deny us our EU rights. The British border in Ireland, upheld by a one—party Unionist state, partitioned our country and denied us our basic rights as citizens. We will never, ever go back to that.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, the principle of gender equality is a core value of the European Union and it is enshrined in our Treaties. The goal of achieving gender equality is crucial to ensuring that the EU policies reflect the perspectives and interests of both women and men. However, there is still a long way to go to reach gender equality within the European Union and it is regrettable that gender mainstreaming is not consistently implemented in all EU activities, which prevents the effective implementation of measures to combat gender discrimination and promote gender equality. The Union should ensure strategic measures are put in place to enable the Member States to respond to women’s rights violations and to ensure Member States’ active promotion of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. In this context, I call on the Member States who have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention to finally do so. I indeed believe that the Istanbul Convention – the first legally binding international instrument on preventing and combating violence against women – can bring change and have a real impact on the lives of women and girls in Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. Mr President, today we are debating four very important reports: on citizenship, enhanced cooperation, the political control that the European Parliament must exercise over the Commission and on the implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Each of these reports had to be the subject of a special debate;  I would like to insist a little on the issue of enhanced cooperation, which exists anyway. There is on the occasion of Schengen, there is, of course, also on the occasion of the functioning of the euro area and it must be a process open to countries wishing to take part afterwards. I would like to point out that we need to consider whether, at this stage, we should also provide for specific provisions, special arrangements, a special regime for certain countries within the European Union that are facing very specific problems, such as Greece, which has just come out damaged by the Memorandums. In other words, to obtain, for a certain period of time, regulations-exemptions from specific rules in order to enable its economy to breathe. Let us also think of this dimension as a way of operating differentiated integration.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, I would like to say to the rapporteurs that their reports are good and cover many of our concerns. We agree on the importance of the creation of EU citizenship and the rights attached to it. However, these rights are not fully implemented. We want a Union where citizenship is linked to residency, where gender equality is fully effective and where the right to political participation is fully implemented. After the economic crisis, and with the current humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean and the increasing attacks against women’s rights, EU citizens feel that the EU should do more to protect their rights. The report on the implementation of the Charter assesses its state of play and makes recommendations to improve it. Despite the weak implementation of certain provisions, we expect that the House will not miss the opportunity to send a clear message that Parliament is committed to strengthening the application of the Charter in full, including social rights and the rights of refugees and ensuring gender equality.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I would particularly like to make a few comments on the Bresso and Spinelli reports. I would like to thank Mrs Bresso for the good cooperation, and I believe that we are also making progress in the development of our joint report from last year in order to strengthen the rights of the European Parliament in the overall concert, but also the necessary institutional projects to take us forward. Let me mention one particular point – this is the leading candidate process that is being raised here again. This will be the key issue for this House – everyone must be aware of this. Will the electorate decide in future who will be President of the Commission, who will be President of the European Executive, or will it be done in the back of the way? And that can only be done if the Council accepts what is in the Treaty. It can only make one proposal, in the light of the outcome of the European elections and after consultation with the European Parliament. And this European Parliament must be able to find a majority for a candidate in order to make a proposal. That is a crucial question – and does this House have the strength to do so? I believe that we should support our leading candidates, regardless of party, to campaign in this way. And to Mrs Spinelli, I would like to make a point: we have campaigned actively for this Charter of Fundamental Rights. But this is not a question of political implementation. A Charter of Fundamental Rights is there to examine whether legislation complies with these fundamental rights. And if it does not have this level of fundamental rights, then it can be brought before the European Court of Justice to do so. That is the crucial question. It is not a program point by point to make this in legislation. I believe that we must learn this if we are to make progress here.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, among the set of reports we are discussing here today, I would like to refer in particular to the important report on European citizenship which I have accompanied as shadow rapporteur for my political group. And I begin by thanking our fellow rapporteur Maite Ruiz for the excellent spirit of cooperation we have maintained and which has made it possible to come up with a report which, I believe, is a good contribution by this Parliament to qualifying democracy and strengthening European citizenship. This report comes at a crucial time for the European project. At a time when this European project is under violent attack, next May's elections are decisive for the future of this European Union that we have built over the last few decades. So now, more than ever, Europeans need to gain full awareness of their status as citizens and make use of their first right of citizenship, the right to political participation through voting. In order to do so, a pedagogical campaign to raise awareness of citizens' rights, starting with the right to vote, is necessary, a major campaign, therefore, against abstention.  And we must also take over and recognise the truly European dimension of these elections and that they take part without obscure interference through social networks. Only then will we have european citizenship that is up to the expectations of European citizens and which qualifies our democracy.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, rapporteurs, the principle of the transfer of powers under which the EU acts within the limits of the powers convoluted by the Member States is essential for my party. Because the reports on EU citizenship and the Charter of Fundamental Rights are ambiguous about this, my delegation will vote against it. As regards the implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights in the EU's institutional framework, there is also work to be done for our own European Parliament. For example, my practical experience shows that the interpreters sign language do not receive the same treatment as the interpreters spoken language. This needs to change. The Bresso report contains elements that we support and others that we do not support, such as the emphasis on the Spitzen candidate process. In the Lamassoure report, we appreciate the suggestions that Länder such as Flanders should play a role in closer cooperation. Thank you very much.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Madam Bresso and all the other shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work on this report. I will concentrate on the rate of participation in EU elections, which is usually low, diminishing at every election and consequently threatening the legitimacy both of the elections and the EU. There is one main reason for this: voters do not feel that there is a straight connection between what they vote for and what policy they will get. Because of the complicated decision-making system, if they vote, for example, for the Socialist Group to be the biggest here, it is not at all sure that they will get more socialist politics in the EU, nor a socialist in charge of the Commission. Strengthening the link between the results of the election and policy, through the Spitzenkandidat procedure, may make European voters more prone to vote. It is creating a more visible and more direct link between what you vote for and what you get. And ultimately it is increasing interest in the elections and enhancing the legitimacy of the EU, and thereby that of democracy.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this joint debate covers several important themes dedicated to the current and future shaping of European integration. The functioning of the EU, serving the interests and the daily problems of people in all the 28 Member States of the European Union is in focus, and here we have the red line between fundamental rights to political control over the Commission. And indeed, colleague Bresso, the Council should not be left out. Thanks to the rapporteurs for their input, ideas and to all colleagues working on them. Let me stress one central challenge to all these various themes and, in particular, those reports dedicated to future development on enhanced cooperation, as well as the one increasing the control of Commission. We have not only to underpin our ambition to give a strong statement that this Parliament wants to be a greater player in the European Union political framework. Thus I call on Parliament to take the opportunity of the new term and the incoming Commission to make full use of its prerogatives and tools to strengthen its position as a major player for the next five years. Including a stronger political will to use existing tools can significantly enhance Parliament’s weight and role vis-à-vis the Commission.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr Vice-President, do you allow me, first of all, just a very small moment that I would describe as a little more intimate? I would like to turn to Mr Lamassoure because it is his last report that is being presented today and I would like to pay tribute to him, on behalf of the parliamentarians and in particular the French parliamentarians, even if nationality has nothing to do in this space. He has honoured this Parliament and has made particular sure to try to exchange, through groups and through our different stories. Thank you, Mr Lamassoure, thank you for this report. I was going to say that it was just a bit of feelings - and I will go very fast - but, in the end, these two reports, that of Mercedes Bresso and alain Lamassoure, reveal a very simple thing: the European Parliament first wants to get closer to the Commission, it wants to work more closely with the Commission, but it wants a Europe that is more democratic, more transparent, more transparent, more social, more respectful of the law. That is the shared responsibility we share. Mr Timmermans, I know you have the same feeling, we have to do it, the future of our Union is at stake.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I won’t try to speak on four different reports in 90 seconds, but there are some rare moments of agreement between eurosceptics and federalists even, when it comes to the European Ombudsman and holding EU institutions to account. But what troubles me most is the report on European citizenship. It seeks to impose an EU identity upon citizens in countries across Europe. That’s not a European identity – you can feel European while still considering these structures, these institutions to be bad for democracy and bad for accountability. And if there’s one thing that we should realise by now, that should be absolutely obvious by now, it is that the state cannot impose identity on the people. We’ve got more calls for taxpayers’ money to be spent to attack any anti—EU dissenting voice. And when you define pro—EU as being good and anti—EU as being propaganda, when the state dictates speech and opinion, you erode democracy. And then to cap it all, there is the suggestion that Europe Day – 9 May – should be made into a bank holiday across Europe, to bribe voters with a holiday to like the European Union more. Don’t get me wrong, in the United Kingdom especially we definitely do need more bank holidays, but I wonder whether 29 March or 23 June might be a little bit more fitting.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i believe that the above reports are in the flight forward that the centralists of the European Union, the federalists of the United States of Europe, have been deploying as they feel the end, not only of this legislature, but also the possible end of what I would call the comfortable majority of EPP and Socialists that over the past two decades has made this European Union a closer ever Union. , the ever-increasing integration of a centralised unitary state. When the EU critical vote emerged so strongly from the election result in 2012, reassuring words were initially used to pretend that the message had been understood. But since Brexit, this has been the radicalism of yesteryear in Parliament, with the aim of expanding far-reaching integration as quickly as possible. Ladies and gentlemen, you have unashamedly brought out that strategy with the Bresso, Brok and Verhofstadt reports. And today you reinforce it. I could still accept your concept of so-called closer cooperation if it were the harbinger of flexible European cooperation à la carte, but in your vision of European integration it is simply part of a fateful whole. This has to stop, ladies and gentlemen. We reject your reports and, after the elections, we will steer, wherever we could as an ENF, both in the Council, in the Commission and in this European Parliament, on a fundamental revision of European cooperation, away from your federal integristic vision. Thank you.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, for states applying the law of origin, namely jus sanguinis, citizenship is a property, a privilege acquired by the birth of a person by parents belonging to the same race and nation. That is why citizenship is not just a legal link between people of common origin; It is a cultural, cultural and social bond based on a sense of common national consciousness. For this reason, European citizenship is a vague and deliberately confused situation with citizenship, which is simply the legal relationship of the national, that is, the citizen to the State to which he belongs. European citizenship has been invented simply to abolish and destroy nation states. It is for this very reason that Greece's left-wing government is massively promoting the granting of citizenship to illegal illegal immigrants in order to gain the right to vote and destroy Greece.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Mr President, fundamental rights are a concept that everyone will support wholeheartedly. Problems only arise when these rights start to proliferate and it becomes impossible to know whether a right is fundamental or not. We are currently in the midst of an inflation of rights. Second, when we raise the question of rights, are we focusing on law or on politics? If you do not keep the two separate, we politicise the law and legalise politics and that is not compatible with democracy. Third, if we frame everything in the language of rights, then compromise, the keystone of democratic politics, becomes difficult to attain. The underlying dynamic of rights is a moral imperative, and morality is all but impossible to compromise. Finally, if we are indeed dealing with fundamental rights, these must apply to everyone, even-handedly and indeed equitably. If this even-handedness is absent, we create privileged groups and exclude others. That is the high road to trouble, to serious trouble indeed. Look around Europe today to see what I mean.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work The Charter is undoubtedly at the heart of the European Union. It combines all the civil, political, economic and social rights of European citizens and guarantees them these rights, freedoms and principles, in relation to the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies of the Union, and binds the Member States in the implementation of Union law. I would like to thank Mrs Spinelli for her comprehensive report. Not only does it underline the outstanding importance of the Charter for citizens, but it emphasises, above all, the need for all the institutions of the Union to ensure respect for fundamental rights in all areas of the Union's activities. This includes strengthening the crucial position of the Fundamental Rights Agency and making better use of its expertise. In this regard, the report calls for the Agency's regulation to be revised to enable it to deliver opinions on EU legislation on its own initiative. This includes the Union's obligation under the Treaties to accede to the European Convention on Human Rights. Four years ago, the ECJ presented an opinion on this subject, which shows the difficulties involved. In this sense, I believe that the Commission is called upon to come up with constructive solutions in order to overcome the legal obstacles to this accession. I hope that this will be tackled as soon as possible.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. To briefly refer to the previous speaker, it will have to prove that the implementation of fundamental rights – which are already valid – should protect against attacks by the institutions. I have my doubts that this will work better in the future than in the past, especially since the question of the rule of law in the European Union is quite questionable, after what has happened here in recent years. But much more interesting is the question of whether, within this European Union – in this state – there can actually be something like European citizens – who think European – within a European nation-state. This is certainly a dream that many dream of. I can even understand that, but it has nothing to do with the reality in the nation states, and above all it has nothing to do with the reality of the state of this European Union during the Brexit chaos.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I think it is important that the court has ruled that the rights and obligations arising from EU citizenship cannot be unduly restricted by the Member States. So all EU citizens are equal, and we must also help politicians to enforce their rights. However, the current situation shows that there are still a lot of differences. That is why I would like to draw attention once again to the indigenous or national minorities in Europe, who have been part of Europe for centuries and enrich the continent with their language and culture. Many of them also expected more from Article 2 of the Treaty of Lisbon and the provisions of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Article 21 of the Charter expressly prohibits discrimination on grounds of belonging to a national minority, but unfortunately its effectiveness is not always adequate. I remind the honourable Commission and colleagues that indigenous minorities will not be fully equivalent citizens of the EU until a comprehensive EU protection system is in place for them. In this respect, we have high hopes for the minority safe pack initiative.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, obviously, in order to be the subject of a comprehensive vision, the implementation of the Lisbon Treaty requires a great deal of expertise. And, in this expertise, as you are, it seems to me, a candidate for the presidency of the Commission, I invite you to take a close look at some of the elements that we have put in Mrs Mercedes Bresso's report on the role of the Secretary-General, as the Ombudsman prepares to confirm, her view that this appointment procedure should be revised. There are, I think, loopholes that need to be addressed, and I have no doubt that this is one of the issues that you will have to address in your campaign. I would also like to say a word about Mrs Spinelli's report, which, in Amendment 17, proposes that the scope of the charter be reopened. This is the famous Article 51 of this charter, which was introduced at the request of the British who did not want the rights so defined to be applied directly to our fellow citizens. I believe that after Brexit, if it takes place, we will have to look at this issue, even though I am aware that it goes beyond implementation and implies change.

name: Michał BONI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you rapporteur for your excellent cooperation! The report assesses the effectiveness of the Treaty concepts in order to bridge the gap between European integration and the potential of European citizenship. There is no contradiction between being a citizen of a country and a sense of national identity and citizenship and a sense of European identity. Only closed heads of nationalists do not understand this. After all, each of us, as a citizen of an EU country, has European citizenship which gives many freedoms and privileges as a result of real integration. As always, in addition to privileges, there are responsibilities, even participation in elections. The 'This Time I Am Voting' action to increase turnout is important, because the results of this election will determine the future of the Union. The report proposes a European Statute for Citizenship, which will be gathered from various Union documents on civil rights and opportunities and democracy building through participation. There is nothing more important today than to awaken the need to participate in European democracy by influencing decisions. Citizens' participation in shaping the EU agenda reinforces their sense of co-responsibility in the European project. The lack of active participation develops a sense of uncertainty and threats, fuelled by populism. The participation of European citizens in European democracy must be more strongly supported by civil society. This is where democracy is practiced on a daily basis. For the coming term of office, this report is for full implementation.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, we are talking about European citizenship, and I would like to remind you that this is just about making Europe. Because living as Europeans anywhere in Europe, in any nation, and having the same rights as nationals, this is precisely the great vindication of this report. And I would also like to add to the praise given to Mr Lamassoure on the report on enhanced cooperation. I would like to say that enhanced cooperation is one of those elements which is the way to build the Europe that we have to do. Because national differences cannot be a stop to the will of a group of countries— most countries — to make Europe. There is too much heterogeneity, there are too many differences, but there is a world calling for Europe to work together and do more things together, and enhanced cooperation is a necessary instrument. That is why I would also like to thank this report, which has to set the route for this Europe of the future that most people want to build.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Timmermans, in my opinion, Parliament must have, exercise strong instruments of control over the European Commission. I will tell you about a situation concerning Romania and the CVM mechanism. There is now a suspicion in my country that up-to-date data is not used in my country or that the data is not verified or accurate. With this suspicion, which immediately spread to the media, Romania addressed the European Commission through the Representation of this institution in Bucharest in order to clarify the issues that aroused the suspicion of associations of magistrates in Romania. As a report drawn up by the Commission is clear, it is humane, so to speak, for that institution to try to justify the way in which that report is drawn up without the necessary objectivity. I have no doubt that the response that will come from the Commission will be one that we all know in advance. I believe that such a referral could have been directly checked by the European Parliament through the specialised committees on a case-by-case basis so as to avoid the waste of time and for Parliament to exercise control over the Commission.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the Lisbon Treaty is, as it is known, practically a rewrite of the European Constitution, which was rejected in referendums. With minimal corrections, citizens were given what they did not want and for which Europe was not ready. Thus, a contractual framework was created for a federation that still does not exist in reality and is not supported by citizens.  In this legal vacuum before and after every European election, the Union institutions beat each other for supremacy, and thus we have obtained a system of Spitzenkandidata through far-fetched interpretation, on which there is still no consensus. Eu co-operation between the EU institutions in good faith, rather than a power struggle, is the first precondition for a better functioning of the Union.  It is necessary to raise the level of political and professional responsibility in order to avoid murky scenarios such as last year's disgraceful appointment of a new Secretary-General of the Commission for which no one was held accountable.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Mr President, very few people out of here or from the institutions know that 9 May is Europe Day. Since it is not festive, it is a totally invisible day, and what is not visible does not exist. And it is oblivion, together with fear, that threatens our coexistence. So let us remember that the European project is a great tool for peace, for solidarity, for post-war social conquests. To do this, let's make Europe Day a holiday across the European Union. In the face of oblivion, more memory. We highlight what we have in common, the everyday symbols shared among all European citizens, because those who do not remember their past are doomed to repeat it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union has resulted from an attempt to give a social appearance to an integration project which, by its headquarters and its policies, is markedly antisocial. This document also constitutes a minimalist and reductive acquis, vis-à-vis, for example, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, national constitutions - such as the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic - or even the Social Charter of the Council of Europe. Recent years have left the bare discompatibility between eu action and policies and the realisation of economic and social rights. The European Union has been a blocking factor and not a rights promotion factor. We look at the results of the European semester, economic governance, the budgetary treaty, we look at the action of the Eurogroup, the European Commission, the troika's interventions, authentic rollers compressors of fundamental rights.  It is increasingly clear that the fundamental rights of peoples assert themselves, and will assert themselves, against all this panoply of instruments that constrain their sovereign development.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I am a proud European and I am happy to say that that does not devalue my British citizenship, for me it only enhances it. I like having multiple identities. But if Brexit happens and the UK is no longer a Member State, I will no longer be a citizen of the Union and nor will 68 million others. And it’s important for you to bear in mind that only 17.4 million voted to lose their EU citizenship. European citizenship has no equivalent anywhere in the world. It’s one of the finest achievements of the European Union and it should be celebrated. It has allowed us to travel, work, study, trade and fall in love across 28 borders. Losing our EU citizenship will be an enormous loss to the British people, to its businesses and the services that we provide with our closest neighbours. The UK Government has promised settled status to all those who have come to the UK legally under the derived rights of the EU law, but sadly this is not the case. I need just to finish with this: with less than 50 days to go, the rights of Zambrano carers are still not resolved. So, with thousands of families in limbo, the UK Government should immediately honour their rights.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, recent changes in the legislative process have led to the need to strengthen parliamentary control procedures.  However, the European Parliament is not making full use of its instruments of political control of the executive, for a number of reasons, some relating to the institutional structure of the Union, others concerning changing interinstitutional dynamics. In the absence of loyal cooperation on the part of the Council, institutional practice does not, in fact, allow adequate budgetary control, leading to a serious lack of compliance with the Treaty's obligations.  I agree with Mrs Bresso's proposal to open negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament, in order to ensure Parliament's right of access to all information on how the Council's budget is implemented. I also believe that the Council cannot avoid answering Parliament's written questions or taking part in hearings and debates on the implementation of its budget.  In the absence of such cooperation, I think that Parliament should only grant discharge to the Commission, ensuring that no section of the Union's budget is followed without proper control.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Mr Timmermans, there are many of us who in this European Parliament have followed, not with interest, but with a very positive assessment, their commitment to better regulation, an improvement in the functioning of European law. But here we are also talking about the implementation of European law already in force, in particular the one that strengthened this European Parliament like never before in history, with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. And that is why I believe that, without thinking of res reviewing the Treaties to further strengthen the European Parliament, the parliamentary function which distinguishes a Parliament that deserves that name should be better fulfilled. To begin with, demanding that the Commission respond accurately and, of course, immediately, calculated over time, in accordance with Parliament's mandate to the European Parliament's initiatives. Secondly, the quality of the Commission's replies to the European Parliament, which leaves much to be desired. There are many of us who regularly get angry when we receive inan responses from the Commission, routine, which in practice signify a contempt for the true dimension of the European Parliament as a political control body for the Commission's work. That is why we believe that a commitment to improving the quality of responses would be a huge step forward in respecting this European Parliament.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened to the different perspectives in this Parliament on what it is to be a citizen and on the issue of an ever-closer Union, and I want to start by adding my own perspective, after 33 years now, first as a soldier, then as a diplomat, then as a Member of Parliament, then a Minister, and now as a Member of the Commission. It would be impossible for me not to acknowledge that, in those 33 years, European citizens from east and west, north and south have grown closer together. In that sense, an ever-closer Union is something that I have seen happening in my lifetime. It is not anybody’s dream to impose a ‘superstate’ or something of that nature. It is about citizens sharing, more and more, the same values and coming closer together on what they think is important for them and their children. Who could say today that a Polish citizen living in the European Union is less free than a Polish citizen before Poland joined the European Union? Nobody could say that! Who could say today that any citizen, in any Member State, has lost her or his identity because of the European Union? I honestly believe identities are more protected thanks to the European Union, thanks to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and thanks to all the legal norms that the European Union and its Member States have adhered to. So let’s not turn things around. Let’s see them in the right historical perspective. I wanted, at least, to share with you my perspective. I respect all the other perspectives, but this is mine, from my experience. I want to add that the reports we’re discussing today are part of an ongoing process of institutions trying to work within the legal order that we have, the Treaties, to try to improve the situation: not just creating more power for themselves but doing something about our citizens’ worries, and finding answers to the big challenges. And, boy, has the European Union been challenged in the past 10 years! Crisis after crisis – and, every time, this Parliament has responded with great responsibility to those crises, working together closely with the Commission, sometimes not so closely with the Council, but all three of us trying to find solutions. These reports reflect the wish of the majority of this Parliament to do an ever-better job, and the Commission will be on your side to try to improve its activities, to work together to improve our performance for European citizens. I would invite you to join me in trying to convince the Council to take similar steps forward. I think this is important. I want to end on the issue raised by Alain Lamassoure. Chers collègues, chers parlementaires, je voudrais vous dire que la pensée d’Alain Lamassoure, qui est convaincu que nous pouvons encore faire un grand nombre de choses au sein du traité que nous avons aujourd’hui entre les mains, est une réalité politique qui nous pousse à agir, sur la base de ce qui est écrit dans les rapports, mais aussi avec une volonté politique en cherchant une majorité au Parlement européen. Certes, cette majorité ne sera pas la même qu’auparavant, certes il y aura beaucoup de travail à faire, mais je crois vraiment que les traités existants nous offrent de très nombreuses possibilités. Un jour, il faudra changer les traités mais, pour le moment, nous devrons travailler avec les traités existants. Et ce que M. Lamassoure a écrit dans son rapport nous conduit à chercher des réponses aux défis d’aujourd’hui et de demain, au sein des traités, en rapprochant l’Union européenne de ses citoyens. Je m’adresse maintenant directement à Alain Lamassoure, en reconnaissance du travail qu’il a fait au Parlement européen, en reconnaissance du travail qu’il a fait pour l’intégration européenne, afin d’aider l’Union à relever les défis d’aujourd’hui et de demain, et aussi, si je puis dire, pour son amitié, son intégrité et sa pensée vraiment très européenne. Merci, Alain.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner Timmermans, I think it is very clear that at the moment we cannot be shy or certainly unambiguous or cowardly.
