Because we have to defend the European institutions, among others, this parliament, which is democratic, and the Commission, which is making it possible for policies that have European added value to solve problems that each of the small countries could not solve in this real world of the globalised 21st century. It's not a whim of identities, of course. You have to have a very closed identity and that seeks homogeneity—that is, cutting people off their freedoms—to think that here we are trying to impose some kind of identity. Nothing further from reality. However, we have to explain to the citizens that there are those who do not want them to have more rights as European citizens, that they do not want them to have the right to complete what European mobility is, that they do not want investment, that they do not want social issues so that young people, especially young people, can live more fully and move from one place to another. That there are those who look in a suspicious way, as if it were something embarrassing, that we can have a common day, a European Day. Well, some of us, of course, have no cowardice, and we have no ambiguities, and we say it clearly. I hope the Member States say that we can have a common day. And common values are not at all infiltrating any kind of identity. Identities are multiple, and if not, you read Amin Maalouf.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would first like to thank Pascal Durand, Ramon Juregui Atondo and you, Mr Vice-President, for the very kind words you have had for me and also thank, for their applause, all those who look at us on the internet. I would like to add a very important point, and I believe, again, Mr Vice-President, that you will agree with this analysis, one of the reasons why enhanced cooperation has not worked sufficiently is because none of the three institutions have really organised themselves to carry them out, to take them seriously and to take them seriously and to appropriate them. Basically, on the Commission's side as well as on the side of Parliament, when we say that there is enhanced cooperation, we understand that some States are interested in this and that it is not really Community. And as governments themselves change, on the Council's side, what is a priority for some governments at some point is no longer a priority when there have been electoral changes in the countries that were the initiators. And that is why we recommend in our report that every institution, including the European Commission, organise itself: will it take a special Commissioner? This question could be decided by a future President of the Commission. Should an ad hoc committee be set up in our Parliament?  Rather, we recommend, whenever there is enhanced cooperation, that a subcommittee be set up in the Standing Committee and that we try to resolve this issue, which we have never settled in the European Parliament, because there had been no majority so far. I hope that things will change with the future Parliament. We must ensure that it is a matter of going to the vote, those who are elected by the citizens to whom the decisions will apply are, of course, those who vote, and that those who are not elected by the States in which enhanced cooperation will not apply participate at that time, in the spirit of the treaty, in the deliberations and discussions, but not in the vote.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Tomašić, I would like to remind you that most of our countries have ratified this Treaty twice – the first time as a Constitutional Treaty, the second as the Treaty of Lisbon – and that your country has entered the European Union by ratifying it. So its legitimacy is indisputable, and it is a serious nonsense to constantly question it as you do.  Returning to our reports, I believe that all these reports are an example of how the Treaty of Lisbon also offers many instruments to make the functioning of our institutions clearer and more transparent. And each of these reports goes in this direction: to make the functioning of the institutions more democratic.  In particular, in my report, we very much address the need to take into account the complexity of the European parafederal system, and therefore a problem of vertical control, because there are many executive entities – and the Commission alone is not the executor of all the activities related to directives and regulations – but also horizontal. The issue, for example, of the enormous role played by the agencies, whose control escapes Parliament very much, if not in terms of budget.  So the problem of preventing the European institutions from being accused of excessive bureaucracy stems from this too, from the impression that the citizens have that this control ultimately escapes everyone a little. It escapes the main executive, which is the Commission, escapes Parliament, is even more likely to escape the Council, and is becoming more and more complex.  I therefore believe that work of greater transparency, clarity and strength in control should be done, or will have to do so, in the next term of office, as there will be.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to conclude by insisting on the crisis of the last decade. It has increased the Commission's powers of direction, which in many Member States are not always considered legitimate and democratic. It is a question of giving it back this very fragile legitimacy without a more systematic reference to the Charter.  Commissioner Malmström once said that, in negotiating TTIP, the European executive could not take account of objections from civil society. He said: 'I have not received a mandate from the people of Europe'. It is obvious that in this way the institutions appear distant, hostile to bottom-up movements.  The challenge of sovereignty must be met with a sovereignty that is shared, yes, but based on the needs of the various peoples to see their social and civil rights respected. If we do not take this into account, if we create a confrontation between sovereignists and Pro-Europeans for electoral use, we will necessarily fall into the language that is no longer political but theological in which Donald Tusk fell, according to which there would be a special place in hell for those in Britain who negotiate badly to leave the Union. We will forget that at the heart of the Brexit issue are European rights and primary law, as my colleague Julie Ward explained very well, not some sort of last judgment made in history and achieved before time.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 12, 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. This is the heart of Europe that we are discussing here: the implementation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This charter was an unprecedented turning point in our history. With it we are much more than an economic community, we are above all a Union based on the rule of law and human rights. Nevertheless, behind the fine statements, I regret that this historical text is undervalued and under-exploited, to the detriment of European citizens who are losing an opportunity to take advantage of a treaty that protects them, for example, from discrimination on the basis of sex, origin or religion. Text under-exploited in particular by States because of the difficulty in applying it as the scope of national law is vague and poorly defined. Our parliamentary report contains many solutions in this area: to produce guidance on how fundamental rights should be taken into account by states or to revise the scope of the charter. The political situation in Europe is very gloomy in terms of fundamental rights but the best response is to continue to affirm our values and strengthen our institutions

name: Kārlis ŠADURSKIS
text: Writing. – The REPORT of the AFCO Committee on the exercise of EU citizenship had a clear objective of assessing citizens' rights in EU framework law and suggesting ways to better demonstrate the benefits of EU citizenship and promote the integration of society. However, I find it totally unacceptable to have amendments that link to any extent the concept and benefits of EU citizenship with residence status, or who seek to increase the range of languages used by the EU, including the languages of minorities from different regions in official EU communication. Firstly, the EU's fundamental laws state that EU citizenship, the privileges and rights associated with it are due only to nationals of EU Member States. Attempts to link EU citizenship to residence status in an EU Member State disparage EU citizenship and make it a purchaseable commodity rather than an advantage for nationals of Member States. Secondly, the EU has 24 official languages – the official languages of the Member States – where you can communicate with the EU institutions. The recommendations to allow official communication with and within the EU institutions in minority languages are a cheap pre-election stunt that is categorically disapproved.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – As a shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE Committee), I am disappointed to see that the final report on EU citizenship does not include any references to the protection of national minorities, despite the strong references accepted in the LIBE Committee. It is difficult to understand that – even though approximately 8% of EU citizens belong to a national minority and approximately 10% speak a regional or minority language – more than 10 years after the signing of the Lisbon Treaty the EU has still not developed a common EU framework to guarantee these citizens’ rights. In the years that have passed since the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty, disillusionment has grown in the hearts of many such citizens, as the EU has not only neglected to adopt legal acts for their protection but has also failed to sanction Member States which have started curtailing acquired rights. It is time that the EU acknowledged the special contribution of autochthonous national, ethnic or linguistic minority communities to European diversity; time that it stopped turning a blind eye to their concerns; and time that it took seriously its duty to protect them and to guarantee their rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Paulo Rangel, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on a draft Regulation of the European Parliament laying down the statutes and conditions for the performance of the Ombudsman's duties (Statute of the European Ombudsman) and repealing Decision 94/262/ECSC, EC, Euratom (2018/2080(INL) (A8-0050/2019). As I do not yet see the rapporteur present in the Chamber, I shall therefore give the floor, on behalf of the Commission, to Vice-President Frans Timmermans.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, as soon as he is here, I will thank the rapporteur, Mr Rangel, for his work on the report on the Statute of the European Ombudsman. The European Ombudsman is a key part of the institutional system of the European Union and an essential aid at the disposal of European citizens, who are entitled to good administration from the EU institutions and bodies. I would like to commend the Ombudsman’s work in fighting maladministration, which has been highly effective. This is illustrated, for example, by the high compliance rate of EU institutions and bodies with her recommendations, which is around 80%. In this context, we welcome the Parliament’s report on the Ombudsman’s Statute. It is, of course, essential that the outcome of this review fully respects the respective roles of the EU institutions and bodies as established by the Treaty. I’d like to make a few preliminary remarks without prejudice to the formal opinion that the Commission will issue at a later stage, as foreseen in the Treaty. We would agree in principle to amendments that consolidate current practice, which in our experience has worked well. This includes the possibility for the Ombudsman to propose solutions and for the deadline for the Commission to reply to recommendations to be able to be extended by two months. Extending the possibilities for the Ombudsman to appear before the European Parliament would also be welcome as, in principle, is the possibility for the Ombudsman to refer issues to OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. As regards the proposed extension to three years of the deadline for lodging a complaint, we’d like to better understand the reasons for such an extension. We’re not opposed in principle but, to our knowledge, the current two-year period does not seem to have raised any practical problems. In addition, the more time that has elapsed, the more difficult it is for the administration to effectively address the issue raised by the complainant. I would also like to recall that the Ombudsman’s role is to deal with cases of maladministration. Cooperation between the Ombudsman and the Fundamental Rights Agency on national fundamental rights, institutions and bodies should remain within that remit. These are preliminary remarks and the Commission will, of course, issue its opinion on the review at a later stage in the procedure, in line with Article 228 of the Treaty.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. Mr President! And thank you also for mr. Timmermanns' review here. I can completely share it. That is why I am also a little sad that the amendments that we actually had in the Committee on Petitions, where we had a very good working relationship, did not all survive AFCO. I don't know what happened in AFCO. For my part, I would like to mention two matters which are crucial – as Mr Schroeder has said. Mr Timmermanns also touched on – namely those related to good administration. One is that we must have made it absolutely clear that access to documents must be a matter of course and that it is only the extremely rare cases that it cannot be granted. I would very much like to ask that amendment No 9.  The second is conflicts of interest. It is still a major problem in all our countries that there are conflicts of interest in large parts of our administration where it is not enough just to say that you have it. They must not be there at all if the citizens are to trust us. That is why I would ask you to do so! And I would just like to say that these two points, which are already being allowed, are also about giving us strong and proud officials, because it is good for the administration and the officials that there is that security around them.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I think we can all agree that the Ombudsman performs an extremely important function, because one of the factors that makes the European Union viable is its commitment to accountability and to following its own procedures. Sometimes it doesn’t happen, but if this commitment is eroded, then the dangers of arbitrariness, the illicit enlargement of power, the abuse of power even, become real. The function of the Ombudsman, therefore, is to ensure that, in these areas of activity, accountability and procedural consistency are observed fully. In this regard, the institution of the Ombudsman performs a very useful function equilibrating between the different institutions of the European Union. The only problem that arises from this is an ancient one: who guards the guardians? It’s the ‘quis custodiet’ problem. Once upon a time, the proper operation was democracy, which was predicated on the political actors behaving with due regard for self-limitation. In the ideologically polarised world of today, self-limitation has fallen down the memory hole. So, the more guardians, the better.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, my group values and supports the role of the Ombudsman. As the Vice-President of the Commission has pointed out, it is a key institution for protecting citizens from cases of maladministrating in the union institutions. We therefore want this institution to continue to operate within the current institutional framework, but adapted to some issues that have arisen in recent years and on which Parliament has spoken: for example, improving access to documents; for example, protecting or intervening in the protection of whistleblowers; and, for example, also take into account the multiple cases of harassment of different kinds that occur in institutions. But we do not want the Ombudsman — the Ombudsman — to be an actor before the Court of Justice of the European Union. We want you to follow the application of the sentences. We want you to protect European citizens in this regard, but not to be both a judicial actor. And we want you to have greater financial and administrative instruments to do your job.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I think that the functioning of the European Ombudsman has shown that he is acting effectively and that he has performed his role over the years. Of course, we can — with amendments — strengthen its action. I consider the Independence of the Ombudsman to be important. At the same time, it must now acquire the possibility of enhanced research on its own initiative. It has become clear, in practice, that this is extremely important. The Ombudsman checked whether procedures, in particular the avoidance of conflicts of interest, were also respected at Commission level, did the same with regard to the ECB and intervened in matters of publicity and transparency, in particular for the Eurogroup. I think we need to further strengthen the role of the Ombudsman, particularly in the matter of whistleblowers and, in my opinion, give him the right to appear at the Court of Justice of the European Union in favour of citizens' rights.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, what we would like to point out is that Emily O'Reilly's team and the role they are doing since the Ombudsman's Office is very remarkable to us, and that is why we have followed with such interest some of the reports which, more intensely, spoke of the need for access to information not to be at discretion on the part of the public authorities. And while we first had doubts as to whether or not it was a priority to reform the Statute, what we do think is that Mr Rangel has been able to handle the matter in a prudent and very specific way. The changes to be made to the Statute are to strengthen the independence and effectiveness of the Ombudsman's Office. And they're made with finesse, that's why we applaud them. However, there have been amendments to the text which was unanimously adopted in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and our group wants to be a participant in those that follow the path taken by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs with regard to the protection of whistleblowers and in some procedures that concern sexual harassment. Because these are issues where we can make improvements and in this parliamentary process we will try to make it; in any case, what we do mean is that European citizens expect a lot from the European Ombudsman's Office and that we have to live up to that expectation.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the institution of the Ombudsman is an institution that helps to identify maladministration. His statutes are back on the books. It's been the same for 30 years. But life is moving on and we need to make changes. Will you tell me, the harassment in the workplace of the European institutions, an issue on which we have tabled amendments, is something new? Of course it's nothing new. It is a very old wound, but now we are more ready to fight this phenomenon and this is where the Ombudsman must help. I therefore call on you to vote in favour of the amendments I tabled on behalf of GUE/NGL. To send citizens a clear message of transparency and trust: that we listen to their messages and we can be effective.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the reform of the Ombudsman’s Statute is a good opportunity to update its capacity. We want to include in the Statute three competencies. First, on whistle-blowers, we want to make explicit that the Ombudsman should be able to carry out investigations based on information by whistle-blowers, and we want to delete the references to professional secrecy in order to avoid any possible restrictions on future legislation on whistle—blowing polices. Second, on sexual harassment, the Ombudsman should be able to deal with complaints on sexual harassment without exhausting the internal procedures of the institutions. Third, on public access to documents, we want to delete any restrictions on access to documents that narrow the scope of the Regulation on public access to documents. This is how we will continue to defend good administration and transparency.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Mr President, I would like first, as a member of the Committee on Petitions, to commend the work of our rapporteur, Margrete Auken, who shows the very strong link that our Committee on Petitions has with the Ombudsman, and then, of course, to commend the work of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, represented by our colleague Enrique Guerrero. Our group, but it is not the only one - you have heard it - has tabled important amendments to strengthen the role of the European Ombudsman. The Ombudsman is, through the mandate of Parliament, the outpost of citizens to operate the control of the European institutions. To that end, we want to see more access to the documents and any refusal to be justified, if necessary, before the Court. We also want to fight against conflicts of interest: the Ombudsman is there to ensure good administration and we want to strengthen its powers in these matters as well as the protection of whistleblowers, so that the Ombudsman can inform citizens, but also coordinate the various national entities responsible for the protection of whistleblowers. We took as a compass, somewhere, the case of "Selmayrgate". In this case, the Ombudsman played her part and so far no consequences have been drawn. We want to prevent this from happening again and the strengthening of the Ombudsman's rights is a guarantee of the proper functioning of our European democracy.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the regulation updating the Statute of the European Ombudsman is an example of this Parliament's efforts to ensure greater transparency and good administration for European citizens, two fundamental rights provided for in the Charter.  Among the most significant aspects of the new Statute are the provisions aimed at ensuring liaison with the future European Public Prosecutor's Office, should the Ombudsman's inquiries detect crimes against the financial interests of the Union. The protection of financial interests, which includes the fight against fraud and corruption, must be an integral part of the right to good administration.  In this respect, it is also important to provide, in the new Statute of the Ombudsman, for a specific reference to the protection of wistleblowers, so as to allow officials who become aware of cases of corruption and fraud within the institutions and agencies, to bring out these facts without fear of retaliation. This will, in my view, strengthen the fight against these phenomena, for the benefit of the European institutions and citizens.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, just to say that, in our view, the Ombudsman remains an extremely important instrument for addressing maladministration, so that we correct mistakes and avoid maladministration in the future. Improving the way the Ombudsman works is in all the institutions’ interests. So, in that sense, the Commission welcomes the report and, as you know, we will give a full reaction to it later, in conformity with Treaty rules. I want to add one remark about whistle—blowers because this subject was mentioned by several Members. We are making good progress on really increasing the possibility of protection for whistle—blowers in the future and I want to thank Parliament for working closely with the Commission. Let’s hope we can convince the Council to come to a conclusion soon. I have to say this is beyond what I had initially expected, so I do want to express my gratitude to Parliament for working closely with the Commission on this.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Rapporteur, rapporteur. – Mr President, I will speak in Portuguese, but first I would like to apologise to the Chamber, to the President and to the Vice-President of the Commission, for being late. Our way of life involves a lot of flying and when you are flying you cannot control the flight time. I am happy to have been able to attend a significant part of the debate and to speak at the end of it. Mr President, I would like to say that I am very proud to present this report, right away because it has had the unanimous support of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and therefore means that a basis has been achieved here which is a basis, I would say, very consensual within the members of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and that it was from one side of the bench to the other going through all the political groups that are represented there , so this is the first point. The second is that it was extremely necessary to reform the Statute of the European Ombudsman because, perhaps not everyone is aware, but the statute we had was before the Treaty of Lisbon and, therefore, it is really a question here of getting, at least to the electorate, in the 2019 elections, a text which is already in line with EU law which has been in force for almost ten years. I must say, moreover, that it is also a matter of great pride that this is one of the cases in which Parliament has legislative initiative and is therefore a unique case from a constitutional point of view and is therefore also an important report to that extent. Having said that, I would like to say what the two principles led to the making of this report. The first was: we need a new appropriate statute, but under no case do we want to break with the idea of soft law and soft power associated with the Ombudsman. The power of the Ombudsman, the power of the ombudsman is a soft power, it is a soft power, it is an informal power. The day he is a party to a process, on the day he has binding interventions, even in very finished domains, he loses his power. One of the reasons why the European institutions, the various bodies of the European Union, trust the Ombudsman is because they know that their power is not binding. Your authority and strength come from your weakness, come from your frailty. Now there were some proposals and some attempts to make a kind of proxy the ombudsman. Now the ombudsman is not a proxy, the provider is not a prossecutor, it is not a tax ministry and therefore, in this sense, it is not a ministero pubblico, as the Italians say and therefore it is essential to maintain this soft power and I believe that balance we have maintained. Then the second concern was to strengthen the independence, impartiality, exemption of the Ombudsman, giving him all the means to act, ensuring that he can have access to all bodies and entities and can have access to confidential information although, of course, it is bound by this confidentiality. But this can be very important because often to reach some of its conclusions, in the various investigations that opens, in the various steps it makes, the ability, on the one hand, to access confidential documents or confidential information, but maintaining confidentiality effectively gives it this status. So what we did was also strengthen some of its guarantees of independence even in its financial status, etc., was to give here some, I would say, practical translation to the guarantee of independence, impartiality and exemption of the Ombudsman and, therefore, to maintain its status of soft power. I used to say that these are the two big weapons of intervention, then there are small adjustments, small adjustments, in the rights of complaint, in a set of small matters, which I think improve, but do not break with what is the tradition of an institution, which so far has worked well, and finally, it is often said, even in football, that, as a team that wins does not move. And so in a team like this, which is a winning team, which is that of the European Ombudsman, of course we move as little as possible, we move the essentials to strengthen its status and we are very pleased that a great consensus has been reached in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. I hope that this consensus will also be reflected in a vote in plenary that strengthens the European Ombudsman as a body in which not only European entities, but especially the citizens of the European Union, can trust and trust fully. He's your defender, he's your provider.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 12, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The development of the Ombudsman's role in the constitutional structure of the Union requires that his independence be maintained. It is therefore absolutely necessary to align the provisions of the Statute of the European Ombudsman with the existing Treaties. It is also necessary to ensure that this body continues to play a specific and decisive role within the constitutional framework of the European Union. It is worth mentioning that the performance of the Ombudsman's duties should not depend on other Union institutions, bodies, offices or agencies, either from a political or budgetary perspective. Furthermore, the Institutions, bodies, offices and offices of the Union should be required to provide the Ombudsman with all the information he requires, subject to the Ombudsman's obligation not to disclose such information. I hope that the new statute will strengthen the independence and impartiality of this body.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Commission's declaration on the right to peaceful protest and the proportionate use of force (2019/2569 (RSP)).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, marches, demonstrations and other forms of public gathering are an important expression of democracy, which must be safeguarded. Indeed, freedom of peaceful assembly and freedom of association are enshrined in Article 12 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and are among the essential foundations of democratic societies. They are essential to the common constitutional traditions of Member States and thus of the European Union as a whole. At the same time, in a democratic society these freedoms must be exercised whilst also respecting other freedoms and rights, and therefore may be subject to certain limitations if that is justified by objectives in the public interest, such as the maintenance of law and order. It is also important to remember that, as explicitly specified in the Charter, the fundamental freedom enshrined in Article 12 refers to peaceful assembly. On that basis, and within its competence, the Commission closely follows any relevant developments that could affect this right, and it stands fully ready to take action if needed. In accordance with the Treaties, the Commission can intervene only when an issue of European Union law is involved.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, I wanted to tell you the story of Jupiter returning to Earth. Emmanuel Macron had been elected on a promise: to be a bulwark against the extremes and the "new world" singer. To do so, he formed a parliamentary majority populated by incompetents and relied on a government composed of ambitious inexperienced people and some fine war catches. Two years later, and three fewer ministers of state, the president had ruled everything in his path: intermediary bodies, unions, communities and his own friends. With his arrogance, Jupiter continued his ascent and, to his great detriment, began his apprenticeship when men in yellow came to remind him of the truth of the Earth by occupying all the roundabouts. These scoundrels, these scum, those people who were nothing in his eyes made the Republic waver. From his castle, King Emmanuel decided, under the pressure of their wrath, to drop ten billion euros of measures in favor of purchasing power, on the eve of Christmas, at the expense of the European budgetary orthodoxy of which he is the guarantor. Finally, the President of the Republic descended into the arena of debate in six-hour increments, always televised, in order to confront the consequences of his policy. Sun Tzu invented the art of war; Macron, on the other hand, invented the roundabout. Despite his best efforts, demonstration after demonstration, radicalism took over. Who was responsible: yellow vests or breakers, yellow vests or anarchists, yellow vests or law enforcement? While, on our faces, we barely dry the tears shed for the dead of the victims of terrorism, Charlie Hebdo or the Bataclan, what was not my surprise when I discovered the creation of a prize pool for the infamous boxer hitting a gendarme on the ground.  So I created mine in response, for the benefit of the 1,200 members of the security forces injured during the demonstrations. The result was clear: 130,000 euros for the boxer in front of 1.5 million for the police, with more than 51,000 donors. Morality of the story: the silent and indignant majority woke up, crushing the boxer's prize pool with his participatory generosity. Respect for authority, respect for the Republic, respect for the laws: Jupiter has finally returned to earth and the good people are regaining the respect they are due, and the social justice that goes with it.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The right to freedom of expression and the right to express one's opinion, together with others, on the streets during demonstrations are essential fundamental rights of all European citizens. I grew up in the so-called real socialism – in the GDR – and I know what it means when these freedoms are denied to you, when people are silenced, when they are persecuted for their opinion or even sentenced to prison. Freedom of expression is a very high asset. And that is not high enough to be appreciated that it is fully guaranteed in our united Europe.  This makes me all the more dismayed by images of demonstrations in which violence escalates. Unacceptable is the smashing of window panes, the targeted injury of police officers, the setting of cars or the arbitrary destruction of our streets and squares. A threat to public order and security has nothing to do with the right to freedom of expression. On the other hand, the police must, of course, also ensure that they always pay attention to the proportionate use of resources and measures and that, by acting, they do not, in turn, contribute to the initial end of peaceful demonstrations. If there are disproportionate interventions by police forces – which we have unfortunately also seen on various occasions – they must be fully investigated. The right to peaceful protest must be guaranteed at all times.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Governments have a duty, when required to defend people, to use force directly to defend people or to defend their rights, the independence of their homeland or public order. But every time such situations occur, it must, of course, be subject to both an assessment and a specific legal review. These are undisputed principles. The problem today, however, is that the Authorities of the European Union always assume that the use of force by liberal governments is implicitly justified, and if conservative governments become in such a situation, this is suspicious, then this must be controlled, it has certainly been violated by someone else's rights. I regret that President Timmermans is not here with us to answer this: these double measures show how much respect for minorities is at stake in the life of the European Union today, because respect for weaker countries is precisely respect for minorities.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, for years in the countries of the Union, income gaps have widened and thrown too many of our fellow citizens into precarious, if not even poverty, in poverty. It is unbearable that over the past decade, ordinary workers worldwide have seen their incomes increase by only 2% per year on average, while the fortunes of billionaires have increased by 13% a year, or six times faster. A system that produces such results will not last long. The protests we are experiencing today in several countries, including my own, are largely the result of these intolerable inequalities. Of course, I recognize the right to protest freely and say that it is a fundamental freedom of our political systems. This right, which is enshrined in the constitutions of all our countries, must be guaranteed and protected, especially for the benefit of those who do not have much other means to be heard. But the right to protest is not the right to trash, loot or break the cop. All too often demonstrations whose objectives are noble are taken hostage by small groups of excited, breakers or even looters, who distort their claims and even their legitimacy. The constitutional and legal responsibility of law enforcement is to prevent these groups from harming the safety of persons and property. They must, of course, do so in a proportionate manner and their slippages must be punished. Of course, there are unfortunate victims among the protesters, but that does not justify making those, who defend the democratic order of bloodthirsty executioners. Such an operation serves only the cause of extremists of all stripes and we refuse to be associated with it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, we welcome first of all having obtained this debate on behalf of the GUE/NGL, we regret that Mr Timmermans has left us. We have nothing against you, Mr Vella, but you are not in charge of these matters and it is a pity that Mr Timmermans, who was there just before, has left. Yes, freedom of expression and association are fundamental freedoms and yes, the right to protest is one of the main variations. The obstacles, the repression cannot be general and absolute, they must respect the principles of purpose, necessity, proportionality. We can only be amazed by what has been going on since 17 November with the 'yellow cards'. Tens of thousands of people march across France; most of the protesters are peaceful, but the toll of violence is heavy: thousands of grenades and rubber bullets, 2,228 LBD (defence bullet launchers) since November, 3,200 wounded - 125 by LBDs alone - and several dozen seriously injured, 20 blinders, five hands torn off and even one dead. So yes, we must reject violence, all violence, but we must ban these weapons that are mutilating or even deadly.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, for weeks now, we have been witnessing violence every week. The violence coming from the "yellow cards" has been condemned, but nothing in this violence justifies the use of weapons that are sometimes lethal weapons and the toll is terrible: 188 wounded in the head, 20 blinded, 5 hands torn, all because of these launchers of defensive bullets and grenades. It is only in France, Poland and Greece, where there is an unlimited use of these instruments which, according to medical teams, cause war wounds. So, of course, we are asking for their complete ban at European level. One imagines that if Frans Timmermans were there, and if in Poland or Hungary, freedom of expression were to be banned or restricted and if there were so many injured, the Commission would move and ask a very firm question to Poland or Hungary. Therefore, we call on the Commission to ensure that these weapons are banned. The right to protest, the proportionate use of force, is what underpins a democracy. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I generally agree with you, but I wanted to ask what restrictions on freedom of assembly in Poland are concerned. Rather, it was the European Parliament that criticised the assemblies that took place in Poland. In Poland, yes, the police fired smooth-bore weapons, even the journalist's eye was knocked out, but it was under liberal rule – when the President of the European Council was present.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: (Greens/FTA), answer "blue card." The limitation of the right to protest that I mentioned is a law that has just passed in France where the prefect, and therefore the executive, can prohibit certain demonstrators from demonstrating when, until now, this was obviously a matter for the judiciary. In a democracy, the executive and the judiciary are obviously separate, otherwise it is no longer democracy. So, yes, we are preventing protests. And those who demonstrate, or sometimes simply those who witness a demonstration, may lose an eye or lose a hand. It is unimaginable to be disabled all your life because you participated in a demonstration.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Madam President, it is in support of the countless mutilated members of the 'yellow card' movement in France that I repeat this gesture which they themselves use with all those who have lost an eye in the demonstrations. Their name is Jérôme Rodrigues, Gwendal, Ninef, Arthur, Vanessa, Jean-Marc, Antoine, Fiorina, Alexandre, Jean-Philippe, Ramy, Franck, Anthony, Cédric and they lost an eye in 2018 or 2019 in France in demonstrations. Victims of flash-ball or grenade fire. There is also Eric, broken jaw; Marlene, 62, 11 stitches to her head; Lola, broken jaw, broken teeth. Frédéric, Antoine and Anne, Pierre, Gabriel hand torn off, Zineb, 80, killed by a grenade as she closed her shutters. There are several hundred others. Broken mouths. So I do not defend thugs and breakers, I execre them because they harm all and because they rot social mobilizations. I do not overwhelm the police because, of course, many police officers would like to be "yellow card" themselves. But I say that at the moment there are extremely serious things going on in my country, France. A struggling power gives delusional, irresponsible, senseless orders against its own people. A power that has the power to cuckoo its people instead of responding to them and responding to their just social and democratic demands. It is all the violence of a financial order that is expressed under the guise of democratic power and which is currently unleashed against its own people, who have become aware of its state of servitude. That is not France. So yes, long live the "yellow cards", long live the RIC, long live the Social Republic and long live Frexit.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, freedom to protest is at risk in several European Union states. This is particularly the case in France. Since November 17, 2018, the "yellow cards" have been demonstrating every Saturday in Paris and in most major French cities. The vast majority of them do so peacefully, in accordance with constitutional and legislative rules. Their demands are legitimate, they demand more fiscal justice, more social justice and better institutional consideration of democracy. Yet their freedom to demonstrate is doubly threatened: first by black blocs and other professional breakers, who have been allowed to act with impunity for too many years and who take advantage of demonstrations to commit violence; then, by a scoundrel law, which is about to allow the prefects to prohibit protest to whom they want, without any prior intervention of a judge, on the pretext of such violence. It is the return of a kind of law of suspects, of sinister memory. In the face of this liberticidal drift, I strongly recall that the freedom to demonstrate is consubstantial to democracy and I call on the parliamentarians LR and En Marche, the originator of this law, to pull themselves together.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In order for this debate to take place, it had to take place under such a neutral, unspeeeded title. They are equal and equal here. We cannot simply debate the situation in France, because there are countries in the European Union that are free to instruct, there are those that would like to be istructed, and those that cannot be istructed. As in the classroom: we have a teacher – after all, it is not possible for a student to call in front of the teacher's board, as with us – it is not possible for France to be called before Parliament and to have to explain itself. Secondly, I do not agree with the fact that the police do not have the right to use force, that the use of weapons should be banned. The problem is that our countries are often weak against the strong, strong against the weak, that phones are knocked out of hand ruthlessly to people who do nothing wrong, and when some thugs plunder shops and set fire to cars, they are treated with clear fear and no one has the courage to give instructions to shoot such people with sharp ammunition. Because if someone attacks, it doesn't matter if they have any revolutionary slogans on their lips.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the rule of law in which I want to live guarantees the freedom to demonstrate in safety. One injured during a demonstration is one too many injured. So what about the 1,700 people injured since the beginning of the "yellow card" movement in France? Behind the numbers are women and men who have lost the use of one eye, have a serious injury to their head or shredded jaw. Lives damaged forever. They have been victims of the defensive ball launchers still used in France, the famous LBD, which we want banned in Europe, as advocated by our rights defender. France's policing policy is dangerous and fuels tensions. Everything has to be reviewed. As an MEP, I am learning to draw inspiration from the best of other European states. Instead of restricting our individual freedoms and responding with a security drift, as the French government is doing today with its anti-demonstration law, it would do better to draw inspiration from its neighbours and good practices aimed at de-escalation and dialogue between protesters and law enforcement. I have a question for you, Commissioner: do you plan to strengthen the sharing of good practices, modelled on the Godiac programme?

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, 1,900 people injured, 188 in the head, 20 blinders, five hands torn off, an 80-year-old woman who died as a result of her injuries, hundreds of wiretaps, thousands of preventive arrests, those thrown in jail: this is the result of the repression of the "yellow card" movement and these weapons, which we are calling for. Is all this normal? In addition, in the same period, there was an attempt to search a major French media outlet and criminalize political and parliamentary life. From this terrible record, it is France, in what it embodies, that emerges disfigured. France, once a source of inspiration for the protection of rights and freedoms. I am sad to have to say this here in front of the European Parliament, but I am worried about my country, I am worried about freedoms in France and I am concerned about the authoritarian shift of President Macron.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, on 1 October 2017, the Spanish police exercised disproportionate violence against Catalan citizens. They injured 1 066 people, citizens who were not even demonstrating: they were just voters trying peacefully to cast a vote in a referendum. The whole world could see this terrible police behaviour, which Amnesty International, for instance, denounced as excessive and disproportionate use of force. And yet, so far, none of these police officers nor their political supervisors has been condemned. Far from apologising, the Spanish Foreign Minister, Josep Borrell, keeps insulting the victims of this police violence while stating that everything is fake news. Those who promoted a peaceful and democratic vote in Catalonia will tomorrow be sitting in front of a judge, facing up to 25 years’ imprisonment, while those who promoted state violence against peaceful voters have not suffered any consequences. This is definitely not the Europe we stand for.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner Vella, in my country, France, for several months now my compatriots have been protesting in the streets against President Macron and his policies of social ransacking and destruction of the state, dictated by the European Union: I mean the social uprising of the 'yellow cards'. The protests, which have been going on for more than two months, seriously hinder the government's trying to discredit them by facilitating the introduction of breakers. These ultra-left-line individuals, the black bloc, act with impunity, under the watchful eye of television cameras and these "yellow cards" who are peaceful and are victims of an unconsentible and disproportionate security repression. Nearly 2,000 seriously injured people are reported. Many of these unfortunates, deliberately mutilated by flash-ball shots to the head, have lost an eye and find themselves disabled for life. Far too many citizens suffer fractures and head injuries. Regarding judicial repression, there are 5,000 arrests and detentions, often preventive and tantamount to arbitrary confinement. The harshness of the sentences is excessive in the face of the acts in question. Legal repression is being prepared with Mr Macron's new anti-cracking law. This law, unique in Europe, will give the prefects the power to prohibit demonstrations to any political opponent arbitrarily designated by Macronie and the embarrassing opposition risks being registered in a detention centre or police station. This anti-cracking law will be liberticidal. Commissioner, this is what your Euro-federalist austerity policies are leading to in France: they lead to totalitarian excesses. This serious attack on democracy risks ending in insurrection if it escalates. You won't be able to say you didn't know.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, we have seen unprecedented demonstrations in France over the last few months by the yellow vest movement. Now this is not a protest movement isolated to France, but it is the most forceful and visual across Europe. Why are they protesting? Because of the loss of democratic accountability, because of an oppressive tax regime, because their living standards are being driven down, and because of mass uncontrolled immigration that is changing European nations into something unwanted and unrecognised by their native inhabitants. Above all, it is because of a political elite out of touch with their own citizens. This is exemplified in France by the bankers’ President Mr Macron. Mr Macron is a figurehead for the European Union. Throughout European history, there have been peasants’ revolts against oppressive regimes. The EU is the ancien régime of the modern age, and no amount of state brutality can prevent it being swept away. Vive la révolution.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Articles 10 and 12 of our Charter of Fundamental Rights enshrine the right to come together and express one's ideas peacefully. In France, for the past three months, a popular social movement has been the subject of a systematic and disproportionate repression: defensive ball-throwers and explosive tear gas grenades are used massively while their lethal range is proven and their control impossible. That is why most European states have banned them from their police arsenals. One woman was killed at her window, five hands were torn off, 20 people lost an eye, 188 protesters were wounded in the head and face: they are mutilated. Videos and testimonies show that the majority of the victims were peaceful. By their inherent threats to physical integrity, these weapons are incompatible with the exercise of the right to protest. Their use must be banned on European soil in order to guarantee this fundamental right. For the maintenance of public order, as with any use of force, violence leads to violence and it is up to politicians to avoid escalation: this is the warning we want to raise by proposing this resolution.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: Madam President, much has already been said about the repression of 'yellow cards', I fully agree with it. This criminalization of social movements does not apply only to France. Today begins the trial of Catalan political prisoners, we can only draw parallels. I would like to protest against the obstruction of journalists by members of the security forces, the mass preventive arrests and the organised violence, which is in line with the harshness of the policies carried out today. In addition, the French government passed a liberticidal law in parliament that establishes a real administrative control over the right to protest. This escalation of repression only stirs up violence, to the point that the police unions themselves deplore this deliberate choice of confrontation. Political question, political solution, responding to the legitimate, social and democratic aspirations of the French people as well as European peoples. In the immediate aftermath, the Communist Party introduced a bill to prohibit the use of defensive ball-throwers in policing. Let's continue in this direction.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. When we talk today about the right to free protest and proportional action by the authorities, in democracies in Western Europe, this is always, of course, about police action, and that is right. Unfortunately, the Hungarian people already know that in modern dictatorships it is already a dream for an accountable policeman to take action against them at a demonstration. In Hungary, the dictatorial power is no longer beating the opposition and opposition protesters with private companies, rather than policemen, copying the Russian dictatorship. My fellow Member of Parliament Laszlo Varjú was beaten by private security services in the state media building, and several members of parliament were simply thrown out of the building by armed security guards. Yesterday, an activist protesting against a speech by the Prime Minister, one of my party's activists, was punched by armed security guards with even his glasses broken. Orban is already doing his dirty work not with police, but with private bodies, and the police only have to look away, and prosecutors will ask that no crime has been committed. If we are to adopt a resolution on the other hand, it must be not only about the action of the authorities, but also about the action of private army.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the disproportionate use of force against demonstrations and liberticidal laws spreads in the Member States and we must deal with them, even if it is the responsibility of the States. We dealt with this in a 2002 resolution which deplored the suspension of the rights of demonstrators against the G8 in Genoa.  When weapons with mutilating effect are used, LBD, grenades, it is clear that European rights are violated. I am thinking of the articles of the Charter on the right to physical integrity, freedom of assembly and expression. The rule of law is not only observing laws, it is also protecting these rights. These weapons must be banned in Europe.  The words used by the French government to describe demonstrators gilets jaunes, casseurs, factieux, brutes, echo accusations of violent sedition against Catalan political prisoners and screech with our legal order.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the right to peaceful protest is a key feature of the exercise of democracy in modern societies, and is enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I am therefore increasingly concerned by reports of excessive use of violence against civilians during protests. I believe it’s the duty of governments to determine accurately the balance between ensuring citizens’ safety and providing for a safe space for freedom of expression. This also means that law enforcers must be held accountable in all actions undertaken towards citizens in the midst of peaceful protests. However, the proportionate use of force should be understood not only as preventing any form of physical violence. The fact is that dissident voices can be threatened in more dubious ways, such as wrongful incarceration and intimidation. In my own country, the United Kingdom, 15 anti-deportation activists were recently convicted of terror offences for attempting to stop the deportation of 60 vulnerable immigrants from the UK. I believe this course of action results from a broken justice system and an authoritarian government, and it’s unworthy of a modern, progressive country.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, peaceful protest is an important instrument of expression of dissatisfaction in a democratic society. Some ruling politicians do not look kindly on him because they feel they have the right to do what they want with electoral legitimacy until the next election. This is a rather authoritative view of the holding of power, which does not belong to 21st century Europe.  The Union, in cooperation with the governments of the Member States, should ensure that citizens are free to enjoy their right to free expression and protest in all Member States.  It is also important to maximise the reduce of administrative barriers often put in front of protesters. The registration of the protest rally must be quick, simple and free, instead of trying to discourage citizens with various compilations and levies.  The right to free protest, of course, does not presuppose violence, but violent individuals have a name and surname and should be individually punished and should not be used as justification for the disproportionate use of force against all protesters.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, in a democratic society, the right to peaceful protest against government decisions is not only self-evident but also necessary. However, because the principle that power is corrupted and corrupted applies, that power does not tolerate criticism — not even peaceful — by its subjects. Instead of relying on the power of persuasion and argument, it relies on the power of the police, which it often turns against peaceful demonstrators. Examples are the violent repression of Catalans in Spain and, most recently, the Yellow Jackets in France, as well as the peaceful rallies of the Greeks, who were protesting against the government's decision to assign the Greek name of Macedonia to Skopje. And if for the Yellow Jackets there was an excuse that some demonstrators carried out violence, for Greece there was not the slightest excuse. The government has ordered that tear gas and expired chemical gases be fired at elderly people and children. We here are right to condemn these unacceptable actions, but the solution will be given by the people in the forthcoming European elections and in the national elections.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to protest is a fundamental, undisputed right which must be protected and which, at the same time, must be subject to clear rules. Among them: the protection of people who choose not to protest, often more numerous, the protection of public or individual property, but also, crucially, the protection of those who participate in a protest, that is, especially the right not to be used as a human shield by those who come to protests only to create violence and scandal. I believe that law-abiding protesters must be protected, and those who use such events to be violent and to hijack the purpose of protests must be severely isolated and punished. We cannot accept peaceful protesters being used as a human shield. I repeat: those who are violent must be severely isolated and punished. It is not acceptable for bona fide protesters, between law enforcement and aggressive groups oriented towards destruction and violence, to become victims of natural reactions to violence and provocations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, although the right to peaceful protest is enshrined in both constitutions and international legal texts, what is happening in practice is that governments break up large demonstrations by force. Classic case: in June 2011, in the Constitution, the Greek people had rebelled against the troika and the memoranda. We had constant violence by the Greek government at the time. This was followed in February 2012 by a large demonstration against the memorandums in the Constitution. Again violence by the memorial government. And now, in recent times, the government has been violently dismantling the large rallies that are taking place to protect the name of our Macedonia and our history. He is now attacking the great patriotic movements, the great patriotic gatherings. Recently, in the Constitution, it broke up with chemically peaceful concentration and attacked the elderly, but also earlier, in Pisoderi in June 2018, it did the same. Shame!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for the inspiring debate. As with most fundamental freedoms, there are also boundaries for the expression of free speech and for the right to assemble. When demonstrations turn violent and when there are instances of hate speech, it is for the authorities of Member States to maintain law and order, subject to judicial review, and to ensure that the rights and freedoms of others are not endangered. In doing so, and while pursuing the legitimate need to uphold security for citizens and property, the authorities of the Member States must ensure that freedom of assembly and freedom of expression are effectively respected and protected, in accordance with their national legislation and international obligations. The European Union, through the Fundamental Rights Agency and the Agency for Law Enforcement Training, supports the exchange of best practice and includes handbooks on respecting fundamental rights in police activities.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have received, in accordance with Article 123, paragraph 2, four motions for a resolution from the regulation. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, February 14, 2019.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Commission's declaration on large predators (2018/3006 (RSP)).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am happy tonight to address, at Parliament’s request, the issue of large carnivores – iconic species of the European landscape. This debate is timely because, given the discussions taking place in many regions in Europe, my colleague Commissioner Hogan and I have jointly addressed a letter to all the EU environment and agriculture ministers explaining the Commission’s approach to this issue and highlighting the support we provide, and I am happy to do the same in this House tonight. Having suffered a very serious decline in most areas of Europe, large carnivore populations have been recovering in recent decades, and returning to countries and regions of their former range. They are protected species under the EU Habitats Directive and their recovery is a contribution towards nature protection in Europe and towards halting global biodiversity loss. However, I am fully conscious of the challenge that the return of these species presents, especially in those areas where they had been absent for many decades and in rural areas with extensive livestock farming. That is why, for several years, the Commission has been supporting the active involvement of all relevant parties in finding suitable and acceptable approaches to reconciling the conservation of large carnivores and the legitimate interests of the people concerned. This work includes supporting and co-chairing the EU Large Carnivore Platform, bringing together key stakeholder groups to facilitate mutual understanding. Through the implementation of a European Parliament pilot project, the Commission is also helping to establish regional platforms, to foster dialogue among stakeholders and local authorities, in the areas where conflicts generated by the return of large carnivores are more frequent, for example in Romania, Italy and Spain. Projects under the Programme for Environment and Climate Action (LIFE) also contribute significantly to supporting the active involvement of all those concerned and a participatory approach, in order to find solutions based on coexistence. The Commission is aware of the fact that, at local level, the wolf may be an additional challenge for farmers in an already difficult social and economic context. In those areas where traditional livestock-protection practices have been abandoned, the return of the wolf certainly entails additional challenges for sheep farmers. That is why the Commission believes that the sector should be appropriately supported to reduce its vulnerability to predation and ensure its co-existence with wild carnivores. Support is available under national and EU funds, through LIFE and rural development projects, and further efforts are necessary to raise awareness among those concerned, so that all possibilities are fully availed of. In November last year, the Commission amended the EU guidelines for state aid in the agriculture and forestry sectors and in rural areas, in order to allow for full compensation, up to 100%, for damage caused by protected animals, including veterinary costs or costs related to the search for missing animals, and for full reimbursement, up to 100%, of investments to prevent such damage – for example in electric fences or livestock-guarding dogs. Regarding the calls from some quarters to address the challenges by changing our legislation, I would remind the House that, under its ‘smart regulation’ approach, the Commission keeps the entire EU legislative acquis under regular review. In December 2016, the Commission published the results of the fitness check evaluation of the EU Birds and Habitats Directives – what we called the nature directives. This confirmed that the current legal framework is sound and remains relevant, including as regards the directives’ annexes. All the EU institutions, the Member State governments and the record high number of citizens – more than 550 000 – who replied to a public consultation have supported such conclusions and confirmed that the Birds and Habitats Directives remain highly relevant and are fit for purpose. Therefore, the Commission has been devoting all its efforts to helping Member States and stakeholders to improve the directives’ implementation, addressing the weaknesses and challenges identified in the fitness check. To that end, in April 2017, we adopted an Action Plan for Nature, People and the Economy, to be implemented by the end of 2019. This action plan contains important elements related to the challenges of conserving large carnivores and addressing the associated conflicts. These include, firstly, the update of the guidance document on species protection under the Habitats Directive; and secondly, continuing and expanding support for the Large Carnivore Platform at EU and also at regional level. Thirdly, greater use of rural development measures will be promoted to support prevention of livestock predation by large carnivores. Fourthly, there is the increased LIFE funding for nature projects, including for the protection of species and for coexistence. Fifthly, on-the-spot missions, ad hoc meetings and nature dialogues will be held to discuss problems and solutions with authorities and stakeholders. Sixthly, a peer-to-peer support mechanism will help Member States’ authorities to learn from each other in terms of implementation on the ground. The final element is the update of the prioritised action frameworks, which identify the financial needs related to species protection, including for damage prevention, mitigation and compensation, in view of the upcoming EU financial perspectives for the period 2021 to 2027. The updated guidance document I mentioned is a work in progress. It is being drafted in very close cooperation with Member States and with stakeholders. After a first round of consultations, a second draft is currently being prepared and will be subject to a new round of consultations in the coming months. The updated guidance aims to deliver on the commitments in the Nature Action Plan to ensure clarity and consistency in the interpretation of the Habitats Directive, taking into account the recent case law of the European Court of Justice. The Commission will not propose any new rules or legal obligations. The guidance document will provide the Commission’s view on interpretation of the species-protection provisions under the Habitats Directive. Honourable Members of the European Parliament are of course welcome to share their views on the draft guidance with the Commission. All these measures are aimed at helping national authorities and the relevant stakeholders. However, it is for the relevant national authorities to decide on the most appropriate measures in each case, in line with EU law.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the approval and implementation of, inter alia, the Habitat Directive, it was intended to improve the sustainability of Europe's natural ecosystems; endangered animal species could benefit from their actions. However, it has had very hard effects on one of the most important species in the rural ecosystem: farmers and their families, with significant and constant economic losses. The wolf, the bear, the lynx have seen its population improve. And now, for example, the wolf in Spain has even a favorable state of conservation in large territories. However, reality has shown that this directive is incompatible with traditional extensive grazing, which is precisely one of the activities in the rural world that we want and must protect. The damage to farmers is constant and the European Directive has not been accompanied by sufficient budgetary measures to alleviate the enormous losses they cause to cattle, sheep and goat farmers, and therefore these farmers are the most vulnerable species. In free decline, the producer, who now has no way of dealing with these policies which cause him so much damage and which did not sufficiently take into account the effects they would have on livestock activity in the rural European world, which is still in reverse, in abandonment of an activity that is part of the cultural heritage of rural Europe. The issue has reached such an extent that, even European appellation of origin and geographical indication foods, which depend directly on extensive livestock for their raw material — for milk – cannot take place. Idiazábal, Ibores or Roncal are also species that will disappear if we do not have enough livestock. We must keep the livestock farms extensive and we have to do it with money, gentlemen.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: On behalf of the group, Madam President, 12,300 victims are the number of livestock taken away by large predators for France. More than 1,000 victims a year and the Commission tells us and repeats that the means of protecting herds are sufficient. Everything's fine. As long as the breeders apply them correctly, that is, they always equip themselves more and more. More dogs and more fences, always higher for that matter. This arms race, Commissioner, makes these spaces infrequent and sometimes dangerous. Will outdoor farming become incompatible with tourism and other mountain activities? And if so, what will happen then to all the species of protected flora and fauna that also depend on a well-conducted pasture? Commissioner, what to answer to this cruel paradox that we ask our breeders to maintain our biodiversity while leaving them to themselves in the face of attacks from these great predators, regardless of the economic and psychological impact they are suffering. Commissioner, this cannot last any longer, the Commission must once and for all hear the pain of these farmers in our rural areas.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, in the last year the wolf has also re-established itself in my country, the Netherlands. As you can imagine, farmers are very concerned. In 2018, 165 sheep were bitten to death in my country alone. DNA testing has shown that this was done by wolves. This is of great concern, especially in a country like the Netherlands where space is very limited, and people and animals live very close together. Mr. Commissioner, do you agree with me that, now that wolf population has increased, it is time to evaluate the situation and review the status? And when was the last time the Annex to the Habitats Directive was revised? The situation is not static, but dynamic. What opportunities do you see for local or regional management in densely populated areas? I call on you, Commissioner, to take a balanced decision in good time and to update the annex where necessary, so that good management is possible and a good balance is found for humans and animals. Thank you.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We have discussed the issue of 'big prey' on several occasions in both the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on the Environment. However, the people in the regions with wolf presence expect concrete action from politics. According to the study presented to the Committee on Agriculture, there are around 17 000 wolves living in Europe. Without regulation, as in Germany, for example, stocks double every three years. This means that by the end of 2019 we will have 34,000 wolves. Shepherds and farmers are tired of being held back with the eternally identical statements and endless debates about the favourable state of conservation. We have finally reached the point where flexible management, adapted to the actual real situation, must be made possible. To this end, we need a corresponding adaptation of the Habitats Directive in its infancy. The completely excessive protection of a single large carnivore must not be above the equal protection of many other species.  It is not only the grazing livestock farmers who are now – quite rightly – demanding more action. In the Swiss canton of Uri, a popular initiative to regulate large carnivores was adopted yesterday with 70%. Reality, not naive wishful thinking, must be reflected in our rules. Especially in sensitive and extremely important areas, such as alpine regions, the preservation of grazing livestock must take precedence over the presence of large predators. So we need wolf-free regions.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is undisputed that large predators are indeed a danger to grazing animals. There is a potential for conflict between farmers and the protection of these species of wild animals. However, Natura 2000 already contains the flexibility for these situations. Article 16(1) of the Directive states that Member States may depart from the provisions of Article 12, which prohibits the killing of protected species, for example to prevent serious damage to crops and livestock farming or for other overriding reasons of predominantly public interest, including those of a social and economic nature. So it is a question of better organising the coexistence between nature conservation and agriculture. It is a question of not leaving livestock farmers alone with their problem, of taking preventive measures, of carrying out proper wildlife management, and of full unbureaucratic compensation, Commissioner Vella, as you said. It is not appropriate to reopen the directive. All we have to do is implement them properly.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, wolves, bears, large predators are suffering a very harsh attack on several fronts. This attack culminated in the shameful call to remove them from the protection afforded to them by the Habitats Directive.  Among the ranks of those who want to do wolf skin are hunters and farmers who are increasingly moving from words to deeds. Ignoble actions that must be stopped as soon as possible, because coexistence between man and these species is not only possible, but is also a value to be protected.  Culling is not the solution, as shown by studies showing that prevention is far more effective. In addition to not allowing to reduce attacks on livestock, killing natural predators such as wolves and bears is an act that disrupts the ecosystem, increasing for example ungulates and wild boars, which in turn interfere with agricultural activity. What is more, there are non-bloody ways to live with these animals, such as the use of acoustic or visual deterrents, or even the use of trained dogs.  I am convinced, as Commissioner Vella also said, that large predators enrich the territories in which they are present, and I am thinking, for example, of activities such as wolf watching and the various projects co-financed by funds such as LIFE.  I will end by relaunching the message recently launched by the Minister for the Environment, Sergio Costa, a strong and important message that must go beyond the Italian borders: wolves and bears do not touch each other.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, the wolf is a major problem in Europe and, Commissioner Vella, we have talked about it many times. The European Commission has still not drawn up any guidelines. Wolves' poaching continues. Or are they actually wolfhound hybrids? In Schleswig-Holstein, the Green Environment Minister Albrecht is now even going to shoot problematic wolves, and he is right.
