The wolf is no longer endangered in its survival, but itself threatens other endangered habitats, plants and animals, for which even national park De Hoge Veluwe – Natura 2000 area – warns us. Why is the Commission not tapping naive regions in the Netherlands, for example? Why are there still no guidelines to manage the wolves that cause real livestock damage? So shoot it. The slaughter of sheep herds and the threat to fragile ecosystems are unacceptable. Article 16, but certainly Article 19 of the Habitats Directive, is concealed by activists, but also by civil servants, whereas Article 19 has been requiring European countries and the Commission since 1992 to update the annexes to the latest state of affairs. And that never happened. Commissioner...  (The speaker is interrupted by the President.)

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the positive trend for populations of species considered to be at risk in the Union shows that the Habitats Directive is bringing all the desired results in terms of protecting biodiversity. Results that, however, cannot be to the detriment of our farmers, farmers and shepherds, who daily come to terms with the damage caused in particular to large predators. We can no longer afford to declassbicate this damage to simple side effects of an otherwise positive phenomenon, such as the recolonisation of these species. In addition to cruelty to animals on the farm, each attack has economic consequences that often put at risk the livelihoods of those operators who, despite the thousand difficulties, continue to avoid the abandonment of entire territories. We need, Commissioner, a European action plan that can no longer be deferred, which will enable us to identify concrete and immediately applicable actions in order to combine our ambitious biodiversity targets with the safety of farmed animals and the economic survival of our farms.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President! Large predators are animals that we hear have successfully protected in Europe and their stock is increasing.  In Slovenia, too, in the last eight years the bear stock has increased by one third, the stock of wolves has increased, and in recent years a series of jackals have penetrated our area, which are causing increasing damage and problem to farmers, especially livestock farmers. On the other hand, farming is being abandoned in mountain-hilly areas, which is why the forest border is also coming down and is getting closer to those who make a living from livestock farming.  The matter is also becoming untenable for people who are either walkers or tourists in these areas, so what we are talking about is that the protection of these animals is being protected in this area and, on the other hand, the protection of people. One of the appropriate measures is also a blow, and this one, if it is professionally shown, must also be done. There are too many of those who are far from wolves, far from the bears... (The President shall withdraw the speaker's word.)

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to deplore the fact that today the left side of the House, the Social Democrats and the Greens, have jointly succeeded in preventing a question on oral answers on the subject and also in preventing the resolution. In this way, the topic of "wolf and big predators" is probably a bit softened in the pre-election period – anyway. The fact is that, since 1992, we have had legislation that protects the wolf and other predators. But then the situation in Europe was completely different: in Europe at that time – or at least in the European Union at the time – the wolves were in fact almost threatened with extinction. Today we have 20 000 wolves and they are causing increasing problems. The regions and the Member States need more flexibility.  I really appeal to you, Commissioner, for you to finally take action here. They have promised it many times, but in fact nothing has happened. What worries me most is that your services are currently working on so-called guidance documents, in camera and certainly to the exclusion of this House, which will bring less flexibility rather than flexibility. At least here you should look over it and prevent us from making the problem even bigger than it already is.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Vella, the subject we are discussing is particularly serious, as you can see. Because the European Union has indeed made an effort to strengthen and preserve the great predators, these large carnivorous animals, but you realize that the situation has now escaped and this is, it seems, the case in all the countries of the European Union. Especially in Greece, we now have a huge number of wolves and bears, resulting in huge problems for farmers. They cannot guard their herds and cannot graze, especially in forests and places at high altitudes. In the countryside, but also in the cities — even in Thessaloniki, boars appeared, for the simple reason that wild boars were forced to descend to the lowlands, because the areas at higher altitude are full of wolves and bears. Specific measures must be taken and, above all, compensation should be given to farmers for loss of livestock.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for the debate. We fully understand the challenges linked to the conservation of large carnivores and I am convinced that, through a collective effort if we all play our role, we can help rural communities to further develop in coexistence with large carnivores. The Commission is maintaining its promises. Many of the actions in the Action Plan for nature have already been delivered and all the others are under preparation. I am confident that, by the end of this year, the full set of actions promised will be delivered as planned. We are willing to continue helping the national authorities and other relevant stakeholders with financial support, guidance, exchange of information and good practices, but again it is for the relevant national authorities to decide, in line with the European legislation, on the specific measures or approach that are most appropriate in each regional context.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: in writing. – I live in Castile and León, which is one of the three largest regions of the EU. The population is mostly concentrated in 14 population nuclei. This community is divided by the Douro River. North of the river, the wolf is a kinetic species, to the south, where I live, no. My province, Avila, is by far the province most attacked by the lobes; 273 attacks in 2017, and in the first half of 2018 alone there were 748 certified attacks, 75.1% more than the previous year. Avila is the Spanish province most affected by the wolf due to its "uncontrolled expansion". Livestock is a very important economic activity in my community and my province. Livestock fixed to the rancher in rural areas. Without proper regulation, the wolf expels the farmer from its natural environment, impoverishes it and hinders generational renewal. This circumstance is profoundly compounded if the demographic problems of generational ageing and depopulation of the rural environment suffered by my province, Avila, are added to it. Public authorities must protect the farmer from the south of the Douro and, in the singularly, the rancher of Avila. The EU must commit to the solution.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Union established legislation in the early 1990s to protect endangered animal species in the Union and their natural ecosystems. This is m.in the Birds and Habitats Directive. As a result of their existence, a number of animal species, which were on the brink of extinction in Europe, began to rebuild dynamically. This mainly applies to large predators such as wolves, bears and lynx. Initially, the mountainous and peripheral regions were mainly affected. Today, however, the problem is becoming more common – predators attack livestock and even humans, even in densely populated areas. Wolves are particularly burdensome, causing increasing losses to breeders, forcing them to close their herds and invest in security. However, the greatest losses are caused by wild boars destroying crops on a massive scale. In the area of aquaculture, cormorant and otters are the source of significant damage. There is no doubt that the Union's environmental policy is needed and delivers tangible results. However, it is necessary to develop solutions that strike a balance between the conservation of endangered species and agricultural activity.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Ramón Jáuregui Atondo, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the state of the debate on the future of Europe (2018/2094(INI)) (A8-0427/2018).

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the various shadow rapporteurs who have helped us build this report which takes shape fundamentally on the basis of what has been the existential crisis of the European Union, which Juncker himself called an existential crisis and which generated the proposal for five scenarios on the future of Europe. What Parliament does, in short, is also to collect the contributions of prime ministers and heads of state who have appeared over the past two years and to try to offer what the proposal is, the scenario, in which Parliament feels mostly. The report actually describes a whole set of circumstances which force us to 'rethred Europe'. Firstly, because we recognize serious problems in the economic governance of monetary union; because we recognize the serious social effects of austerity economic policies, especially in southern countries; because we know that Brexit forces us to reflect on a europe that is likely to be different in the wake of the UK's withdrawal; because there have been significant inconveniences between different countries, especially in the area of migration policies; because new problems, such as internal security and external security , arising from the first of the problems of terrorist attacks, and the second of a very conflicted neighbourhood – force us to a new conception of European defence; because there have been many dysfunctions in the functioning of the Union in recent years. One way or another, what we come to say is that Europe needs to set up a roadmap. And what the report offers are some reflections, thick ideas. The first, for example: nationalism is not the solution. We are all too small in the European Union to face the great challenges and this is a common denominator of virtually every prime minister who has appeared here. And, in that sense, I would say that the European Parliament's bet is Mr Juncker's fifth scenario: to do more together. I'd say: do better what we can only do together. A second line of reflection, no doubt, is that integration, a better integration, has to overcome several problems that have been detected as structural. For example, unanimity for certain issues: taxation, foreign policy, etc.; the timid use of enhanced cooperation; the temptation of many states to abuse the right to an 'A la carte Europe'. And so we could continue with dysfunctions that have to be resolved in the coming months. The Commission must regain political initiative, because we believe that the European Council has regained too much power imbalance during the crisis. A more agile, more political Commission; more power to Parliament, with the right of initiative, with the Spitzenkandidaten as a fundamental rule of connection between elections and the presidency of the Commission itself; more control of the Commission. In short, ladies and gentlemen, what this is about is establishing great lines for better integration, to do better what we can only do together. What this debate raises is that the next electoral debate reflects these reflections and proposes to the public a profound reflection - I would say policy - on what the future lines of the European Union project should be.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very right that the European Parliament has become a discussion forum on the future of the European Union in recent years, with prime ministers, representatives of the Member States. I am very sorry that Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babiš refused to come to the January plenary session, which did not actually take advantage of this invitation and did not share his vision for the future of the European Union. The report we are discussing and will vote on states that differentiated integration and political union are the way forward. I think it is true that some challenges, particularly those on defence, external and internal security of citizens, need to be strengthened by common powers. On the other hand, I call for greater respect for subsidiarity and a halt to the flow forward in integration at all costs. Let's learn from Brexit.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. According to the Commission's own assessment, the debate on the future of Europe is reaching one of its most important stages this year, when the Heads of State or Government in Siiben, Romania, in May, put their faith in a Europe that can deliver visible results for citizens. I believe that, if that summit is to be held in multi-ethnic Transylvania, then these results must be truly visible and felt by indigenous national minorities. Siam was once one of the centres of the German minority in Transylvania, which has hundreds of thousands of people, and unfortunately only a few thousand Germans now live in Romania. At the same time, the Hungarian community in Transylvania has one million300,000 people and expects Europe to pay attention to the fact that it cannot use its symbols, that the state only provides the use of the mother tongue on paper, or that the future of medical training in Hungarian is in jeopardy. Thinking about the future of Europe must include the specific problems of national minorities, and this issue cannot remain a matter for the Member States.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Europe and the European Union is at a crossroads. Populism is on the rise. People are feeling that the systems and institutions no longer serve their interests. As elected representatives, it is for us to restore that faith. We must make sure that collectively and collaboratively we work for the interests of the people we represent, whether that be by ensuring that the loopholes for tax evasion are closed, strengthening human and workers’ rights, continuing the peace project that is Europe or ensuring balanced trade deals with countries with whom the EU has the same values – and not undermining human rights while we do it. Now more than ever we need closer ties between EU Member States, working on social cohesion, security, tackling climate change – continuing to strengthen peace at the heart of the EU project. The UK is sadly attempting to leave just when it needs to be a part of the European project, leading not leaving. As Robert Schuman said in 1950, Europe will not... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we remember very well when, in 2016, President Juncker brought to this House the debate on the so-called 'White Paper on the future of Europe' and many of us were angry to see that the Commission did not have a plan, so that it offered us everything from continuing to drag our feet, as we had been doing, to the unrealistic federal leap. But there were two options that were a way out. Enhanced cooperation, which does not mean Europe on demand or of variable geometry, but a coalition of those who really want Europe and are willing to put the necessary resources on the table to achieve it. And, of course, do together what only together we can do. Well, this report on the future of Europe clearly outlines what the European Parliament's position is on this issue, but it will make no sense if Europe is unable to increase its cohesive budgets to restore not only the social model, but its vocation to support and correct inequalities, especially with the less favoured regions: outermost regions, ultra-high-rise regions , farthest and least populated regions are the ones that need the most...  (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the future of Europe is a very important topic, but I'm afraid it turns a bit into a mixture of fear that targets citizens in an election year and good wishes that are hard to achieve. On the one hand, people are afraid of Russian propaganda, irregular elections, fake news, populists or new conflicts in Ireland over a hard border after Brexit, and on the other hand, it offers very few concrete changes to the existing institutional framework that clearly does not work. A good part of the European establishment has remained trapped in the federalist vision of Europe from the 1950s and simply cannot adapt to the new circumstances or wishes of citizens. Anyone else who disagrees with this outdated vision is called populists, often without any basis.  Constructive discussion cannot be conducted by labeling and flossing, two monologues do not constitute dialogue, and without real dialogue we will never find answers to the challenges of the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it is the Europe of nations and homelands that can truly guarantee a smooth European course. The European Union, which must respect national identities and traditions. From then on, very specific measures must also be taken in the field of economic and monetary union. The Stability Pact must be abolished. The policy of harsh austerity must be abandoned. The European Central Bank must become a last resort lender. We do not need a European Monetary Fund. The European Central Bank can play this role, as is the case with all central banks in the States and in the United States and England. A decentralised system of European central banks is needed if things are to work much more smoothly and to allow the monetary sovereignty of certain States, which are in financial difficulties, to be able to pursue an autonomous monetary policy for a certain period of time.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the supposed debate on the future of Europe was, in fact, a debate on the future of a capitalist integration process that confronts civilisational principles and values, the result of the struggle of the peoples of the European continent. The European Union is not Europe. The future of Europe is not confined to the scenarios to which the European Union wanted to circumscribe the debate on its own future. It soon became the case that this debate was nothing but a staging, with conclusions drawn from the outset, what was intended was a justifying exercise of a new escape forward, which deepens the neoliberal pend of integration, along with an even greater concentration of power in the main powers, a practical result of the end of the principle of unanimity which they now openly defend. Furthermore, it is intended to force a worrying militaristic escalation, which poses a serious threat to the peace and security of the peoples of the continent. The future of Europe cannot pass through here. It will be the struggle of workers and peoples that will chart a future more in line with their interests and aspirations.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, it is reasonable and expected that there will be debates in Parliament on the future of Europe, because this is an issue that concerns us; not only us, but also the generations to come. However, I have great doubts as to whether we will be able to find a solution to the problem and not have a debate of literary interest alone. I say this because for many of us, but especially for the european Union's leadership circle, there are obsessions and anchorages which — while it is clear what is happening — do not allow the right procedure to be applied to solve the problems. There cannot be a future in Europe when the principle of unanimity is abolished, so that there is no equality and therefore no cooperation between the states, which is essential to solve the problems. It is not possible to constantly attempt to dismantle nations, national states. It is the Europe of nations and homelands that will solve the problem, with the cooperation of all the Member States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur for this timely and highly relevant report. We have to be clear that when we discuss the future of Europe we discuss whether and how we want the European Union to reaffirm its future in the world. If we want our Union to stay an actor in global politics in the 21st century, to maintain our economic strength, to defend our interests, and to shape foreign policy by projecting our European values of democracy, freedom, openness, solidarity, the rule of law and fundamental rights, then we have to do all what is necessary so that Europe has the internal legitimacy, capacity and means to do that. At his State of the Union address in this House in September last year, President Juncker presented to you his priorities and outlined his vision for how the European Union could devolve by 2025. On the same occasion, he presented a roadmap for a more united, stronger and more democratic Union. In particular, he called for confirming the process of the so-called spitzenkandidaten at European level, completing the governance of the euro area, and for a modern and values-based European budget for the coming years. In the longer run, the Commission’s take on the future of Europe is that we do not exclude treaty change. Today, however, we must not discuss treaty change but focus on concrete policies and on the immediate concerns of our citizens. This is what we are doing. The Commission has by now fully delivered on all the proposals needed to address its priorities. Together with you, the Members of the European Parliament, and the 28 Member States, we have adopted over the last four years, around 250 ambitious legal acts in the areas of investments in the real economy, the digital union, energy union, capital markets union, internal and cybersecurity, border protection, defence, economic and monetary union, trade, research and innovation, climate change, social solidarity, youth and employment. We are thus delivering concrete results that are to the benefit of all European citizens. As we meet today, our three institutions are working night and day to conclude important pending files, such as the European Border and Coast Guard, the prevention of terrorist content online, copyright and a series of contingency measures to mitigate the negative consequences of Brexit before the next elections. It is in all our interests to give it one last push and our joint efforts are already bearing fruit. The European Union is in the sixth consecutive year of economic growth. 239 million people in the European Union are currently in jobs. This is the highest number ever. With this, the European Union is on course to meet its Europe 2020 target of a 75% employment rate by 2020. Youth unemployment has fallen, down from 25% in 2013 to 15% overall, but remains far too high in some of our Member States. The EU is defending a rule and values-based multilateral order as just confirmed by the partnership agreements with Japan, which has just entered into force and which will generate new opportunities and growth both for Europeans and our partners. These results should inspire us to not let up because the task of building a more secure, sustainable and more prosperous and fairer Europe is far from over.  Steadying a confident and collective European course is the best response we can give to rising forces of illiberalism, nationalism and xenophobia and to fears of rising trade conflicts. On May 9 this year, just a few days before the elections to the European Parliament, the leaders of the European Union will meet at a summit in Sibiu, Romania, to reaffirm to European citizens and to the world, their commitment to a united, strong and democratic future of Europe at 27. Let us use this and any other opportunity to send strong and positive messages to our citizens. Let us not allow the doomsayers to weaken or paralyze our Union. Let us convince our citizens, so that at the next elections they will want to vote for a positive agenda, for stability, freedom and prosperity, for a Union that is united, strong and democratic.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 February 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – I consider this report and the debate to be timely, because Europe has recently been faced with internal challenges from its own Member States, which the EP, as the Union's main elected political body, must play a proactive and guiding role in responding to. The chances of re-dynamising European integration, in addition to the major global economic, social and environmental challenges, are now under increased threat from the rise of anti-EU nationalism and populism in Europe, even by some national governments and leaders. As a glaring example, the Orban government is now provocatively weakening the FUNCTIONING of the EU by denying our Democratic Values in Europe by undermining migration policy or a common foreign and security policy. That is why I support all the institutional and political reform proposals that have been formulated so far in our debate on the future of integration to help curb these dangerous political aspirations: citizens' trust, democratic participation, the more efficient, transparent, democratic functioning of the Union, social justice, solutions to prevent the break-up of the EU - if necessary, even treaty change. I consider it particularly timely to apply the Community method and qualified majority decision-making in general, to make the EP election more open and direct, or to strengthen Parliament's role in order to counteract the often deliberate indecision of the EiT. As a Socialist politician, of course, I urge the creation of the political and institutional guarantees necessary for the realisation of the historical task of Social Europe and for the effective functioning of the Social Pillar.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is a short presentation of the report by Ashley Fox, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on a comprehensive European industrial policy on artificial intelligence and robotics (2018/2088(INI)) (A8—0019/2019).

name: Ashley FOX
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I was pleased to see this report adopted in Committee last month and I thank my shadow rapporteurs for working with me to produce a good result. This report sets out Parliament’s position on artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics.  Members may not be aware that Parliament originally agreed we should do a report on this subject in April. We spent the next six months arguing over who should be the lead committee, so work only started in October. This then left us only four months to write the report and bring it to plenary. That was a shameful waste of time. If there is one lesson I have learned from this process, it is that Parliament should rethink how we deal with these situations. We’ve had to work at great speed, and I’m glad that we’ve been able to get a substantial report through within such a short time frame. I wish to record my thanks to my assistant, Lavan, for his hard work.  My main objective has been to ensure that this is a positive report that signals our willingness to adopt this technology and provide the correct conditions for it to thrive. We are at the beginning of seeing the adoption of AI and it will take many years before we see its full potential and reap the full benefits of it. It can make us more prosperous, healthier and create jobs that currently don’t exist. An example that I have used throughout discussions on this file is that it took the best part of 200 years for humanity to reach the full potential of the steam engine. Along the way there was great resistance and I have no doubt there’ll be opposition to the adoption of AI.  There is, of course, always opposition to change, but let us not stand in the way and be a Parliament of Luddites. In the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), we agreed on the need for a code of ethics to guide the development of AI. This should encourage the good actors and deter the bad ones. Working under such a code and ensuring transparency will ensure greater acceptance of this technology. We believe that AI should have a human-centred approach. What is meant by this is that the use of AI should augment human capabilities rather than just replace them. It is sometimes forgotten that when AI and human abilities are combined, they are more powerful than when used in isolation. This has been demonstrated particularly well in the medical field.  It is important that we prepare society for the changes ahead through developing education and training. As AI progresses, it will destroy some jobs and create others. We need to ensure that we have a skilled workforce to take advantage of the new opportunities. This will be one of the most important aspects of ensuring competitiveness on a global scale.  We should recognise that most of the investment in this field will come from the private sector, not the state or the EU. Our Member States must work hard to ensure that they are attractive places to invest.  One final point I wish to make is that artificial intelligence does not have borders. It will operate between and across the different jurisdictions of the world. We should therefore approach its governance with a global mindset. We must ensure that the EU and our Member States discuss this at an international level, and as far as possible develop global standards.  I look forward to hearing what colleagues have to say this evening and to a positive vote tomorrow.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, Rapporteur, Commissioner, Europe has undeniable potential in the development of Artificial Intelligence. However, there are also a number of issues related to the effects to which national and EU legislation has not yet responded. Some Member States are therefore trying to adopt their own legislation to regulate autonomous robots. I believe that it is important for the European Union to respond together at EU level by harmonising the rules. Member States should work together on AI, because we are faced with the same challenges, the same risks, and together we face competition mainly from Both China and America. However, it is not only about competitiveness, but also about the security of the citizens of the European Union, because AI is making progress, but it also poses major security challenges, which is why I welcome the Coordination Plan for Artificial Intelligence presented by the Commission in December. I believe that we need to react quickly.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would really like to congratulate the rapporteur, because, as he said, there were very short deadlines. And he did a great job and very thorough work. I would like to make only a couple of comments: the first thing that was really needed for this report, although there were doubts, I think that a number of amendments – a few hundred – have been tabled and colleagues have shown great interest, and I think we have examined many very important topics for the first time. Of course, the next Parliament will return to this subject on a number of occasions because it is a major challenge for Europe and a changing challenge. But he will have this report as an excellent basis for continuing his discussions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr President-in-Office of the Council. Fox, for his report. I think it does put the issues in the dimension to which they need to be raised. First of all, we are talking about artificial intelligence and robotics, which are already being developed and have created many opportunities and, at the same time, many problems. They create new jobs, but at the same time other jobs are being lost.  From then on, we must focus on establishing an integrated European industrial policy, because on the world stage there is huge competition with the United States and China. If a coherent industrial policy is not implemented so that it can raise investment and, above all, give a boost to the development of robotics, I think there will be too many problems. However, artificial intelligence must be at the service of man and we must have a human-centred approach and not an approach in favour of the profits of large monopolistic companies.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Thank you, Chairman. If we want to move forward with artificial intelligence, we really need to get smarter first. Because if we do nothing, China will be a world leader in artificial intelligence by 2030. And I see you looking a little surprised, because I do not want China to be the world leader, but for Europe to be the world leader. That is why I am so pleased with this report. Because I want Europe to invest in our entrepreneurs, in our whizzkids. They're our doers. They provide inventions that make our lives easier, more interesting and better in the future. These doers are going to make me come to Strasbourg in a self-driving car later – in 2030. These doers, who deserve our support, support from Europe. And there, that's what I stand for. Thank you very much.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, artificial intelligence and robotics contribute to increasing the social productivity of human labour. Increased productivity creates the conditions for real wage increases and a better life, but this potential is constantly called into question in capitalist society for the sake of defence and increased profits. The capitalist appropriation of new technologies, with the substitution of workers by machines, competition between workers and machines, the pressure to monetize capital, boosts exploitation and job insecurity.  But new technologies, instead of taking away some of the work and intensifying and degrading the work of others, could and can, conversely, be used for a significant reduction, without loss of income, of the working time of all workers, reducing work rates, reducing unemployment rather than increasing it. A reduction in the non-reduced working time of wages or social benefits that would apportion the workload of all workers.  This is a very topical fight.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fox, and the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the associated committees, for the very good report on a comprehensive European industrial policy on artificial intelligence and robotics. AI and robotics have great benefits to offer to improve quality of life. For example, precision farming promises to drastically reduce the need for pesticides and AI can also help to greatly improve cancer treatments and save lives thanks to early diagnostics. We welcome in particular that the report addresses all the key aspects, namely, that it is essential to ensure the EU's competitiveness by boosting its research and industrial capacity in AI and to promote the uptake of AI across the economy. That it is necessary to prepare for the socio-economic changes brought about by AI, in particular regarding skills, jobs and social protection. And that we have to ensure an appropriate ethical and legal framework based on the Union's values and in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. The Commission is very pleased that Parliament shares their vision on the development and deployment of human-centric AI and acknowledges the importance of achieving ethical and trustworthy artificial intelligence – the trademark for AI made in Europe. Concerted EU action is also essential to avoid the fragmentation of the overall legal and ethical framework, and it is important that all stakeholders are represented in the process.  I am glad to know that we share the understanding that without sufficient funding, Europe will not be able to regain leadership in AI. Increased funding will be of crucial importance to the digital Europe programme and Horizon Europe, accompanied by the development of a public-private partnership in AI. We should make every effort to realise the promise potentially illustrated in the report for important sectors such as healthcare, energy, transport, agri- food, cyber-security and in the public sector, increasing productivity and competitiveness as well as quality of life at work and at home. The Commission appointed a high-level expert group on AI to draft ethics guidelines covering issues such as fairness, safety, transparency, democracy, personal data protection, dignity, consumer protection and non-discrimination.  The group should finalise its work in the course of March, and the guidelines are expected to be published in early April.  It is encouraging to see the support of Parliament to build on this work for an inclusive and ethical development in the use of AI. Parliament welcomes the creation of the expert group on liability and new technologies. While you regret that no legislative proposal was put forward during this legislature, you will understand that the substance is very complex. That is why the Commission will put forward a report in early summer outlining the broader implications for potential gaps in, and orientations for, the liability and safety frameworks for AI.  We have to build on our own strengths and support the European entrepreneurial spirit. We must be fully engaged and ensure broader and easier access to services for citizens and industry and address socio-economic and legal issues, building on European values. A united and value-based approach to AI will make the European Union a leader in AI and help promote ethical principles worldwide. And this concerted effort is necessary to ensure that European citizens and the economy can reap the benefits such technology has to offer. In conclusion, the European Parliament is uniquely placed in this mission, in particular in informing about the benefits AI can bring while carefully addressing the risks. The Commission is delighted that it can count on the support of Parliament to actively contribute to developing and implementing the comprehensive European industrial policy on AI and robotics. AI can improve quality of lives, greatly contribute to our economic growth and our environmental sustainability.  Let us not miss these opportunities.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 12 February 2019. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – Self-learning machines can help us dramatically reduce road casualties, manage resources more efficiently, reduce our energy consumption, and can be used in many other areas. But in addition to all opportunities, the use of AI systems also carries risks. The use of disinformation campaigns or military use are two areas that we must pay particular attention to. Misinformation created and disseminated by AI can have a negative impact on our society. Autonomous weapons systems and their use present us with major challenges, combined with ethical questions. We must work to ensure that moral decisions and the responsibilities involved always remain in the hands of man and that ethical standards are absolutely paramount! Moreover, artificial intelligence and its application must remain comprehensible to us humans – because we must not allow artificial intelligence to slip away from us under any circumstances. Effective European regulation, covering the full range of applications, taking into account ethical concerns and ensuring the controllability of technology, is therefore of the utmost urgency.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – In July 2017, the Chinese government presented its plan to become the world leader in artificial intelligence (AI). By 2030, Beijing wants to create an industry worth USD 150 billion in this area. Americans are also very active here: this week, President Trump signed a decree that provides for further boosting investment in the American AI market and triggering AI proliferation. In 2018, the US accounted for more than half of global AI investment. USD 19.2 billion was invested in AI start-ups last year alone. The United States, with a market share of 33%, is still well ahead of China, which stands at 17%, but is catching up. The European Union also needs to catch up, which is why the Commission is increasing its annual investment in AI under the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme by 70%. The target is €1.5 billion in additional funding for the period 2018-2020. By 2030, Brussels wants to invest 20 billion euros in AI. Europe needs these investments, as well as a coherent and coordinated approach to retaining talent and patents in the field of AI in European universities and businesses.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The pace of technological advancement is so fast that nobody can fully grasp what is coming next. We can only speculate where Artificial Intelligence (AI) will be in 10 or 20 years. Yet this is not something new – for instance, who knew 10 years ago what a data scientist would be? What is certain though is that the ever-changing digital world will significantly affect our lives. While previously, advances in automation focused on particular industries, like manufacturing, today automation influences all sectors. Automation is the new reality in the workplace and in the forthcoming years we will observe a growing interaction between humans and machines. Research shows that for the past 140 years automation, robots and technology have created more jobs than they have destroyed. Historically, the economy has consistently found space in higher-skilled, creative work as it has eliminated routine tasks through automation. About 10% of jobs we know today will disappear, but the actual challenge is that at least a third of them will change due to digital disruption. Adaptation is indispensable and education (with a capital E) is key.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – This report takes a positive overall approach to artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics and lists a large number of existing and potential benefits it brings to society, industry and specific sectors, such as public administration, healthcare, transport, energy, cyber security, etc. Europe is leading the AI revolution that can substantially improve the lives and conditions of citizens, leading to new business models and playing a key role in digitising economies and transforming our societies.  However, we agree that AI must be in line with European values, respecting human rights and privacy, and measures aimed at education and retraining must be taken when jobs are replaced by robots to ensure a fair transition. Developments in the field of artificial intelligence must be designed, developed and implemented in such a way as to protect the dignity, autonomy and self-determination of the person, i.e. to be human-focused. We want a society supported by artificial intelligence and robotics. That is why the increasing integration of robotics into human systems must be guided by a sound policy on maximising benefits and minimising risks to society.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – With this own-initiative report, the European Parliament adopts a set of fundamental principles for the common values of the Union to be embedded in the main pillars of the emerging digital society. In particular, it stipulates that the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) must be online and respect fundamental rights, freedoms, dignity, privacy and be focused on responding to people's concrete needs. The European Union cannot fail to halt the global fight for innovation and scientific and technological leadership in strategic areas such as AI. Combating this fight with fewer financial resources and with necessary ethical guarantees in the use of data implies opting for a differentiated vision, focused on the positive transformation of industrial and social organization models, measuring the impacts of this transformation and taking advantage of the dynamics of change to increase the competitiveness and intelligence of productive systems, combat inequalities and give sustainability to public service systems , such as health, safety or education and qualification systems. This vision has prevailed in the ongoing negotiation of the Digital Europe Programme in which I represent the S&D Group and must prevail in the development of the digital society in the EU.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).  I will underline ‘one minute’ and we will respect that time slot.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw attention repeatedly to the situation that, unfortunately, is currently on its way to the UK, which is particularly concerning in relation to smugglers who smuggle people through Europe towards the UK. This activity is repeatedly penalised not by the smugglers themselves, but by truck drivers who have nothing to do with this activity. I would like to draw attention to the case of Jiří Sagan, who was sentenced to two years in a French prison, even though the police have in no way shown that he was the one who knowingly smuggled people into the UK. I would like to call on the Commission to really deal with and address the cases of truck drivers systematically, because the situation is unsustainable in the long term.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. 2019 will be the year of elections in Europe. While we are preparing for the EP elections, presidential and parliamentary elections are being held in Ukraine. Ukrainian citizens have to choose from 44 presidential candidates, but only two or three have a real chance. This would not be a problem in itself, but unfortunately the Hungarian community is still facing a difficult situation. The most likely candidates strengthen their voter bases with rhetoric that excludes nationalist minorities, and their programs do not bode well for minorities. In the run-up to the elections, the government will present a new language law restricting constitutional minority rights to TheRaa, the first reading of which has been widely criticised, and the international public has stated that it should be referred to the Venice Commission before it is finally adopted. They are probably not willing to do this because the Venice Commission opinion on Article 7 of the Education Act has not yet been implemented. The majority nation in the country is also skeptical about the results of the elections. The public is dissatisfied with fraud, corruption and does not believe in the credibility of the legislative elite.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, I have asked to speak to say two things. The first relates to the candidacy of Laura Codruța Kövesi for the post of Chief Prosecutor of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. He is a person known and appreciated throughout the European Union. Her appointment should not be a political barter, nor a vote pro or against the Bucharest government, which refuses to support her after dismissing her from the head of DNA for political reasons. I therefore call on all the political groups in the European Parliament to vote for it. In this way, we would show that a person who has achieved miracles in the fight against corruption in a Member State is supported to do the same at European level. The second thing concerns Klaus Iohannis. Mr President, exactly two years ago, the Bucharest Chambers approved a referendum on the anti-corruption fight you promised Romanian citizens. I ask you to convene this consultation on 26 May, the day of the European elections. In this way, Romanian citizens will be able to say whether they want to keep their country in the European Union or, if, as Dăncilă and Dragnea want, they are thinking of returning to an authoritarian regime isolated from other Europeans.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was part of the delegation which, between 24 and 27 January, went to Managua and then I was able to witness the high price that journalists and students pay for the courage to denounce the brutal repression of the Daniel Ortega regime. Universities suffer cuts in public funding to which they are entitled, students, accused of terrorism for having participated in peaceful protests, are sentenced to heavy prison sentences and those who manage to escape can hardly resume their education in the public universities of the countries where they have taken refuge. To silence any dissenting voice, the government shads newspaper newsrooms and, on charges of terrorism, arbitrarily detains journalists and forces others into exile. If, during the visit to El Chipote, I checked the undignified and shameful conditions of the dungeons where journalists Miguel Mora and Lúcia Pineda are detained, I have received reports that these conditions, contrary to what they assured us, worsened after our visit. Lucia was isolated from the other prisoners and Miguel transferred to El Infiernillo. I therefore call on the Nicaraguan authorities to immediately release these political prisoners or allow them to wait under house arrest for the hearing scheduled for March 15.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, I was planning to talk about the effect of Brexit's impact on the outermost regions, but I will use my minute to respond to an attack that has been launched against my country's foreign minister, Josep Borrell, in a debate on the disproportionate use of the police force in relation to events in Spain on 1 October two years ago. Because it turns out of place, unfair and in conflict with the truth. Unfair because these events took place when Spain ruled the People's Party. Miswhere because, under no circumstances was the foreign minister responsible—and is not now—for any use of the police force. But above all, in conflict with the truth, because he has been accused of fake news, when Precisely Minister Borrell is characterized by introducing rigour in the face of manipulation and intoxication , which are left over – and the crunch , which is left over – in the treatment of the Catalan question. Required for dialogue, yes, but in compliance with the Constitution and the law. These events took place precisely because the Constitution and the law were consoted by disobeying a constitutional court ruling prohibiting the support of any consultation.

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the economic situation in Italy in recent weeks, the critical issues that we in the Democratic Party have already pointed out in the bud of the economic manoeuvre presented by Conte are evident.  The Italian economy is stagnant, with the prospect of growth cut from 1 % to 0.2 %, industrial production has fallen to -5.5 %, and the unemployed are increasing. We continue to sail on sight, without realizing that what is at stake is the social resilience of the whole of Europe.  Austerity, born to defend the interests of the few to the detriment of the many, has allowed populism to strengthen. Today, populists risk undermining the European project. In a few months' time we will be in the election campaign and I, in my constituency which includes Campania, Puglia, Calabria, Abruzzo, Basilicata and Molise, will not tire of repeating that Europe must be changed, but with feasible proposals a minute later: less austerity, more social Europe, more investment, more Erasmus for professionals and structural reforms in the economic field of institutional organisation...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, the Trans-European Network programme is intended to improve communication along strategic corridors. In Kent, the M20 motorway is part of that network. Two days ago, the UK Department for Transport (DfT) started a month of works on the London-bound carriageway, with night closures between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. GMT. Great, you might say – improvements to the channel ports are long overdue. But no, the purpose of the closures is to turn part of the motorway into a lorry park to cope with the disruption of a no-deal Brexit. We’ve also seen from the same Department for Transport the issue of a contract to a ferry company with no ships from a port with no appropriate landing facilities.  Now the DfT has since changed its mind and cancelled that contract. It seems that the DfT is allowed to change its mind, but the British people are not. When you are not allowed the chance to change your mind in a democracy, you no longer live in a democracy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, a random parliamentary majority under Alexis Tsipras proceeded a few days ago to ratify the despicable agreement of the Prespas, which sells out the name of our Macedonia and our history. An agreement opposed by the Greek people, who, with their mass rallies, sent the message that they are calling for a referendum on the "Skopian". At the same time as the shameful agreement of the Prespas, Skopje is recognized as an enclosed state and acquires the right of access to the Greek EEZ.  In addition, the same parliamentary majority ratified Skopje's nato membership, involving Greece in a dangerous game of geopolitical rivalries between the European Union, the United States and Russia. Although Skopje got what they wanted, they continue to provoke and still maintain, in their new Constitution, their redeeming claims against Greece. But let them know in Skopje that the Greek people are united and determined and will not accept the sell-off of our Macedonia. Because Macedonia is one and greek.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. It is well known that the Romanian Revolution of 1989 began in Timisoara. In the 30th year of the fall of the Communist dictatorship, hungarians in the city were shocked to learn that they wanted to convert the representative building confiscated during communism, the Hungarian House, into a hotel. To this day, Romania refuses to return the illegally nationalised properties of the Hungarian community and its churches to their rightful owners in their entirety. On the centenary of the country's creation, on the 30th anniversary of the people's uprising in Timisoara, which started with the Hungarian Reformed Church, we rightly demand that our minority rights be respected and that Romania's European commitments be fully fulfilled. Timisoara will be the European Capital of Culture in 2021. The permanent disposal and wrongful theft of the Hungarian House would be a mockery of this and the city's multicultural heritage.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I am proud to be a member of a Parliament that so clearly took a stand in support of the forces that want to bring Venezuela out its deep democratic crisis. There is, of course, still reason to monitor the situation, but we shall continue to support Mr Guaidó's ambition to move the country towards free and democratic elections. On the other hand, this Parliament also did a different favour. It is thanks to our position that my own country's government – which likes to talk about the importance of democracy and human rights – was reminded that it is actually possible to choose between dictatorship and democracy. It took them a week, or a couple of weeks, to take that position, but in the end they did. I am ashamed of my Venezuelan colleagues who have been beaten, tortured, killed. The Foreign Minister's party colleagues and the Left Party chose not to support the resolution, thereby betraying democracy in favour of the cattle of the dictatorship. It's actually just sad.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, tomorrow a trial will begin in Madrid against members of the previous Government of Catalonia and against the two most respected and beloved social leaders in our country. The trial is evidently political. Neither the German courts, nor the Belgians, nor the Scots accept the offences of those accused of detainees, who have been in prison in pre-trial detention for more than a year. A post-Franco, stale and anti-democratic judiciary has taken power, with the support of the previous GOVERNMENT of the PP and with the consent of the current PSOE. This February 12nd reminds me of another February 12, forty-six years ago, when Carlos Arias Navarro, successor to Carrero Blanco, proclaimed what he called "the spirit of February 12". Yes, we will remain in the spirit of black Spain for forty-six years ago, with Franco still alive. Eternal Spain continues to impose itself on modern Spain. And, in this house, Tajani and most of them, no comment. A real shame.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, libraries give access to knowledge and promote the joy of reading, they are an amazing free resource. Now nearly a quarter of library users are under-nines, and surveys show that children of all ages give their libraries a big thumbs up, with youngsters living in more deprived communities valuing their libraries even more highly. However, in Essex a third of libraries face the chop, in a wanton act of cultural and educational vandalism. And closing the library won’t just take books off the shelves: it will rip the heart out of local communities. This half-term, in threatened Essex libraries, we have: ‘Discover dinosaurs day’ at Danbury library, Peter Rabbit fun in Broomfield, and puppets, singing and a treasure hunt at Silver End library. And, week in, week out, libraries host things like Rhyme Time clubs and provide access to the internet. Essex needs its libraries. So my message to Essex County Council tonight is: ‘Stop, think again and shelve this terrible plan.’

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, domestic violence, a concrete expression of the more general violence on women in our society, continues to take on brutal and intolerable expressions. In fact, she will always, in any case, be brutal and intolerable. In addition to the shock and the embedation aroused by the public knowledge of each new specific case, action is needed. Action is needed to prevent, combat and eradicate. Action needs to be done in the effective and timely protection of victims, strengthening social support and access to justice. It is necessary to act in the transformation of the reality underlying domestic violence, to act on the causes of economic, social, political and cultural order that are at the origin of domestic violence, on the psychological dynamics that interconnect with them as a result of dependencies of various order. To act in the fight against all forms of daily violence, more or less covert, in combating all forms of discrimination against women, in wages, at work, in life, at all obstacles to full recognition of equality.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, last week I was convinced personally that hundreds of refugee children live on the streets in the European Union without protection. We know from the available data that there are currently 3 792 unaccompanied children in Greece, 7% of whom are under the age of 14. Most of them don't have parents, they died in the war or they're missing. In Greece last week, I met a six-year-old girl, Zafira, from Afghanistan, who was killed by both her parents during a trip. I was moved by her story, but I was glad that this little girl was lucky because she is housed in a children's facility in Athens, where she is being cared for. But they are among the lucky exceptions, because thousands of other children remain on the street in Greece, and thousands are in various camps and other facilities, where they are waiting to merge with relatives or for better conditions. In this context, I also repeatedly appeal to governments, including the Czech Government, to take these children in.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Mr President, recently, in Romania, information has emerged that no fewer than ten banks have resorted to trust-type cartels in order to manipulate ROBOR. This is the average interest rate at which Romanian banks lend to each other, artificially setting its level. The ROBOR level influences the value of monthly rates on loans in national currency. Depending on the value of ROBOR, Romanians pay more or less for bank loans. We have referred this situation to the Commission and requested urgent intervention to verify how Romanian banks comply with the principle of free competition. An dishonest banking system is a danger to the free market, but also to the direct interests of citizens. There are signs that there have been such problems in other Member States of the Union, and that is why I believe that a Commission analysis is mandatory, but also a broader discussion here in Parliament's plenary, to see what the situation is. I would like together to clarify these issues and, if necessary, to take measures so that the European citizen does not fall victim to the greed of the banks.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: – Mr President, the European elections are approaching, and now we have to discuss about all the missed signals related to the influence of fake news and third state propaganda on the results of the upcoming elections. Some people asked us to limit contacts with the mass media of the Russian Federation. Of course, I cannot deny the problem or fake news and propaganda. It exists really, but at the same time is, it is another important obstacle for the free political process in the EU that makes us to go on in cooperation with Russian TV channels and news agencies. The main reason is the exclusion of opposition and minority parties from the mainstream national media in some EU countries. For example, in our country, Latvia, the only way we can reach voters is to cooperate with the media of neighbouring Russia. I am sure we need a comprehensive legal framework at the EU level in order to monitor and ensure a fair approach for all political forces to the mass media... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, this week sees the biggest comedy festival in Europe, which is the Leicester Comedy Festival, in my constituency, and I congratulate all those involved in it. However, Brexit is no joke for those working in comedy and music, theatre and the arts. These industries make a huge economic contribution and I know people working across these sectors are worried about the potential impacts of Brexit. The ability to travel and perform freely across the EU is essential. Potential tariffs and different royalty arrangements would be a bureaucratic headache for artists. A Brexit recession, with people having less cash in their pocket, would mean people going to fewer gigs and shows. These sectors are worried about Brexit. Whilst we know that the British Government’s handling of Brexit is now beyond a joke, for the real people working in those sectors, these issues are no laughing matter.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the European Court of Human Rights periodically reminds us that freedom of expression applies not only to information or ideas that are welcomed with favour, but also to those that offend, shock or worry. Voltaire had said the same thing, two centuries earlier. Yet freedom of expression is increasingly being unjustified, both in France and in Europe. In France, the law of 22 December 2018 allows any political party, especially the one supporting the President of the Republic, to ask the judge of the referees to stop, during an election period, the dissemination on the Internet of any opinion likened to an inaccurate allegation. It is a formidable instrument of censorship of the opposition, which the minister of justice has already threatened to use against Marine Le Pen. The European Union is no exception. The European Parliament has, in fact, just amended its internal regulation to prohibit MEPs from making offensive remarks, which is contrary to the Western democratic tradition, which guarantees Members the right to say what they want in the Chamber. Unfortunately, this situation is symptomatic of the cynicism of the temple merchants who run the European Union and shamelessly violate the European values they claim to defend.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, we often complain about multi-speed EU integration, but what are the reasons why countries like Latvia lag behind? Some would say it is because of the Soviet legacy but, in fact, that is a cover for the real problems, which are the demographic crisis, massive immigration and disrespect for minority rights. When Latvian citizens voted for accession to the European Union, they voted for a high quality of citizenship, as in all the EU Member States. Now they are frustrated because there is no common European citizenry standard. Many of the democratic deficits attributed to the EU are, in reality, the fault of national policies. In Latvia, 12% of the population are declared non-citizens and are simply cut off from any political participation; 40% are members of the Russian-speaking minority, without any instrument to defend their fundamental rights as a minority. In western Europe it would seem like a bad dream: in Latvia it is reality.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, tomorrow the most shameful political trial the European Union has ever seen begins in Madrid. Twelve people will be tried in Europe for organising a referendum of self-determination following a democratic mandate. This trial is the triumph of state nationalism and the politics of vengeance, but it is the failure of European values and the primacy of politics over repression. Official Europe has failed us. But you know that treating honest politicians as criminals, that abusing and twisting the rule of law to support false accusations, that a nostalgic far-right party of Francoism exerts the popular accusation, you know that all this clashes head-on with European values. But it will be our stubborn defence of these values and European justice itself that will end up repairing the injustices committed and what will make us return to the path of democracy, justice and freedom.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, tomorrow we will vote on the Fisheries Agreement between Morocco and the European Union, which includes the territory of Western Sahara within its area of application, leaving it to the Moroccan authorities to manage resources that do not belong to them. The Court of Justice of the European Union has highlighted in several judgments two aspects which have not been taken into account in the negotiations. The first, that Western Sahara is not the territory of Morocco, and the second, that it is necessary the consent of the Saharawi people, through their legitimate representatives, to negotiate what happens with their lands and with their water. Ratifying this Agreement means putting economic interests above the fundamental pillars of the European Union, such as human rights and respect for legality, not only in the judgments of the CJEO, but of various United Nations Resolutions. Ratifying this Agreement means being complicit in the occupation of Western Sahara and making peace talks difficult to find a just and lasting solution.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, I want to congratulate the Irish Nurses and Midwives for their resolute action against a government that has refused to engage with their legitimate demands. After a massive demonstration of solidarity in Dublin last weekend, the Labour Court has now intervened to provide an offer that the nurses are considering. That the dispute reached this point is a true indictment of the Fianna Gael government and their useless appendage in Fianna Fáil. Nurses have been forced to take their strike action against a backdrop of a deteriorating health service. They are fighting for a better service for all of us and people across Ireland know this, which is why they have such broad public support. It’s no wonder that we have a recruitment and retention crisis in nursing when their pay today is lower than it was in 2008. The Irish government and EU leaders need to realise that their agenda of austerity, low pay and growing inequalities will see increasing levels of opposition among those people, including our nurses and midwives, who are at the coalface. They will though continue to have the full support and solidarity of the Irish people and of Sinn Féin in their ongoing... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The development of the PESCO agreement is really a step towards building a European army, and I am very surprised that many governments are practicing such a policy on short feet and are signing up to this agreement, especially since the Polish does so. We already know what the signing of the Treaty of Lisbon by President Kaczynski before – the fact that Poland is now humiliated in front of the whole world by the European Commission. And if the European Union gains such a military arm, I think we will see that there will be such a common European army that will provide fraternal assistance to peoples at risk of democratic, human rights and gender equality deficits. So I think this is a very dangerous direction, and an ideologised institution like the European Union should not have an army, because it is very dangerous. Moreover, it is a policy of the so-called Europeanisation of Europe, a consistent attempt to free Germany from the consequences of losing wars and to build its own military alliance independent of the Americans.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
